http://arxiv.org/abs/2205.13023v2.title: Self-Consistent Grain Depletions and Abundances II: Effects on strong-line diagnostics of extragalactic H II regions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2205.13023v2.summary: The depletion of elements onto dust grains is characterized using a generalized depletion strength $F_*$ for any sightline, and trend-lineparameters $A_X, B_X$ and $z_X$. The amount by which elements deplete also affects coolant abundances in the gas.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15557v1.title: Extended Line Emission in the BCG of Abell 2390
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15557v1.summary: We report CFHT/SITELLE imaging Fourier Transform Spectrograph observations of the Brightest Cluster Galaxy (BCG) of galaxy cluster Abell 2390 at z=0.228. The BCG displays a prominent cone of emission to the North-West with PA = 42$^o$, 4.4 arcsec in length (15.9 kpc) Strongly-LINER-like emission is seen in the nuclear region which hosts an AGN.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.00067v2.title: The Solar Neighborhood in the Age of Gaia
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.00067v2.summary: Before 2018, accurate distancemeasurements needed to turn the 2D Sky into a faithful 3D physical picture of stars were few and far between. Since 2018, data from the Gaia mission are revealing previously unseen and often unexpected 3D distributions of gas, dust, and young stars in the solar neighborhood.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.01629v2.title: Nature and Nurture? Comparing Ly$α$ Detections in UV-Bright and Fainter [O III]+H$β$ Emitters at $z\sim8$ With Keck/MOSFIRE
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.01629v2.summary: The 100% detection rate of Ly$\alpha$ emission in a sample of four luminous $z\sim8$ galaxies with red Spitzer/IRAC colors suggests objects with unusual ionizing capabilities that created early ionized bubbles in a neutral era. Whether such bubbles reflect enhanced ionizing properties (nature) or an overdense environment (nurture) remains unclear.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.04915v2.title: Stellar cluster formation in a Milky Way-sized galaxy at z>4 -- I. The proto-globular cluster population and the imposter amongst us
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.04915v2.summary: The formation history of globular clusters (GCs) at redshift $z > 4$ remains an unsolved problem. In this work, we use the cosmological, $N$-body                hydrodynamical ``zoom-in'' simulation GigaEris to study the properties andformation of proto-GC candidates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15525v1.title: Euclid preparation. XXXII. A UV-NIR spectral atlas of compact planetary nebulae for wavelength calibration
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15525v1.summary: Euclid mission will conduct an extragalactic survey over 15,000 deg$^2$ of the sky. NISP will obtain spectroscopic redshifts for $3\times10^7$ galaxies for the experiments on galaxy clustering, baryonic acoustic oscillations, and redshift space distortion.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15518v1.title: ZFIRE -- The Gas Inflow Inequality for Satellite Galaxies in Cluster and Field Halos at z = 2
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15518v1.summary: Gas inflow into galaxies should affect the star formation and hence the evolution of galaxies across cosmic time. Gas inflow rates of satellite galaxies rapidly decline after their infall into cluster halos and as they reach the cluster center. At z = 2, the gas inflow rate of cluster satellite galaxies is correlated with the cluster-centric radii and not the host halo mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15516v1.title: A systematic survey of millimetre-wavelength flaring variability of Young Stellar Objects in the Orion Nebula Cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15516v1.summary: High-energy processes are ubiquitous even in the earliest stages ofprotostellar evolution. We report the discovery of an order of magnitude millimeter-flare within just a few minutes from a known YSO. We also present an assessment of the systematic variability effects caused by the use of time-sliced imaging of a complex region.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15514v1.title: Abell 1201: Detection of an Ultramassive Black Hole in a Strong Gravitational Lens
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15514v1.summary: Supermassive black holes (SMBHs) are a key catalyst of galaxy formation and evolving. Measurements of SMBH mass are usually only possible for SMB Hs in an active state. Gravitational lensing makes it possible to measure the mass of non-activeSMBHs. Results are available at https://github.com/Jammy2211/autolens_abell_1201.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15506v1.title: Galaxy interactions are the dominant trigger for local type 2 quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15506v1.summary: The triggering mechanism for the most luminous, quasar-like active galacticnuclei (AGN) remains a source of debate. Some studies favouring triggering via galaxy mergers, but others find little evidence to support this. Here, we present deep Isaac Newton Telescope/Wide Field Camera images of 48 optically-selected type 2quasars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15500v1.title: Turbulence in the Tail of a Jellyfish Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15500v1.summary: ESO 137-001 is a quintessential jellyfish galaxy located in the nearest rich cluster, the Norma cluster. Its spectacularmultiphase tail has complex morphology and kinematics both from the imprinted interstellar medium (ISM) and as a result of the interactions between the stripped gas and the surrounding hot plasma.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15501v1.title: Ongoing hierarchical massive cluster assembly: the LISCA II structure in the Perseus complex
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15501v1.summary: LISCA II is a massive stellar system in the Galactic Perseus complex likely undergoing cluster assembly. It comprises nine star clusters and an extended and low-density stellar halo. The hierarchical structure is mostlycontracting towards the center with a speed of up to $4-5 km s$^{-1}$, while the innermost regions expand at a lower rate.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15498v1.title: X-ray scaling relations of early-type galaxies in IllustrisTNG and a new way of identifying backsplash objects
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15498v1.summary: We investigate how feedback and environment shapes the X-ray scaling relations of early-type galaxies. We find that ETGs with above-average mass experienced systematically lower cumulative AGN feedback energy historically. Three outliers that lie far below the $L X --$T Sl  relation all interacted with larger galaxy clusters recently and demonstrate clear features of environmental heating.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15499v1.title: Mother of Dragons: A Massive, quiescent core in the dragon cloud (IRDC G028.37+00.07)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15499v1.summary: A massive core in the "dragon cloud" (G028.37+00.07 or "Cloud C") has implications for theories of massive star formation. Only a small number of candidates for such massive, monolithic cores are currently known. The cores are very dense and have only trans-sonic non-thermal motions (Ms ~ 1)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15442v1.title: The Need For Speed: Rapid Refitting Techniques for Bayesian Spectral Characterization of the Gravitational Wave Background Using PTAs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15442v1.summary: P pulsar timing array (PTA) techniques for characterizing the spectrum of a nanohertz-frequency stochastic gravitational-wave background (SGWB) begin at the stage of timing data. This can be slow and memory intensive withcomputational scaling that will worsen PTA analysis times as more pulsars and Observations are added.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15431v1.title: Spectroscopic verification of very luminous galaxy candidates in the early universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15431v1.summary: First JWST science observations uncovered a surprisingly high abundance of early star-forming galaxies. However, the distances (redshifts) of these galaxies were, by necessity, estimated from multi-band photometry. Spectroscopic measurements of the precise redshifts are required to validate these sources.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15253v1.title: First observational evidence of a relation between globular clusters' internal rotation and stellar masses
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15253v1.summary: Many Galactic globular clusters are characterised by internal rotation. Theoretical studies of theynamical evolution of rotating clusters have predicted that, during their long-term evolution, these stellar systems should develop a dependence of the rotation velocity around the cluster's centre on the mass of stars. We present the first observational evidence of the predicted rotation-mass trend.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.13293v2.title: Introducing TIGRESS-NCR: I. Co-Regulation of the Multiphase Interstellar Medium and Star Formation Rates
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.13293v2.summary: Massive, young stars are the main source of energy that maintains multiphase structure and turbulence in the interstellar medium. Without this "feedback" the star formation rate (SFR) would be much higher than is observed. Realistic approaches should solve the dynamical evolution of the ISM, including starformation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.05542v2.title: Dynamics of intermediate mass black holes in globular clusters. Wander radius and anisotropy profiles
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.05542v2.summary: We simulate globular clusters with a realistic number of stellar particles on a standard workstation. We measure the evolution of the Lagrangian radii and coredensity and velocity dispersion over time. We find that models with an IMBH undergo core collapse at earlier times, with anapproximately constant central density at core collapse.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15156v1.title: Ultracool dwarfs candidates based on six years of the Dark Energy Survey data
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15156v1.summary: We present a sample of 19,583 ultracool dwarf candidates brighter than z                $\leq 23$ selected from the Dark Energy Survey DR2 coadd data. The objects were first pre-selected based on their (i-z), (z-Y), and (Y-J)colours. They were further classified using a method that compares theiroptical, near-infrared and mid-rared colours against templates of M, L and T dwarf objects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06592v3.title: Spatially resolving polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons in Herbig Ae disks with VISIR-NEAR at the VLT
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06592v3.summary: We use the long-slit spectroscopy mode of the VISIR-NEAR experiment to perform diffraction-limited observations of eight nearby Herbig Aeprotoplanetary disks. We observe two kinds of PAH emission geometry in our sample:centrally-peaked (HD 97048) and ring-like (AB Aurigae, HD 100546, HD 163296, and potentially HD 169142) We find a strong correlation in the disk structure but a difference in radial intensity decay rate.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.14460v3.title: Astrometric Microlensing of Primordial Black Holes with Gaia
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.14460v3.summary: The Gaia space telescope allows for unprecedented accuracy for astrometricmeasurements of stars in the Galaxy. We explore the sensitivity of Gaia to detect primordial black hole (PBH) dark matter through the distortion that PBHs would create in the apparent trajectories of background stars. We argue that the background rate of AML like events due to other sources is likelynegligible.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15030v1.title: Effective Temperature Estimations from Line Depth Ratios in the \H\ and \K-band Spectra of IGRINS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15030v1.summary: High-resolution infrared spectroscopy is a powerful tool for determining the temperatures of stars with no dependence on interstellar extinction. We applied the LDR method to 110 stars obtained with the Immersion Grating Infrared Spectrograph (IGRINS) The temperatures found from our calibrations provide reliable reliable temperatures within $70 K accuracy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15008v1.title: Fundamental effective temperature measurements for eclipsing binary stars -- IV. Selection of new benchmark stars and first results for HD 22064
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15008v1.summary: 20 eclipsing binary stars that are suitable for calibration and testing of stellar models and dataanalysis algorithms. Stars selected are F-/G-type dwarf stars with M- type dwarf companions that contribute less than 2% of the flux at optical wavelengths. The techniques described here for HD22064 can be applied to the othereclipsing binaries in the sample.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.09582v2.title: Dissecting the Mid-Infrared Heart of M83 with JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.09582v2.summary: We present a first look at the MRS observations of the nucleus of the nearby                galaxy M83, taken with MIRI onboard JWST. The observations show a rich set ofamines from the ionized gas, warm molecular gas, and dust. We propose that the diffuse [\ion{Fe}{2}] 25.99 $\mu$m emission might be tracing shocks created during the interactions between the hot wind produced by the starburst and the much cooler ISM above the galactic plane.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14876v1.title: Gravitational polarization of test-mass potential in equilibrium polytropic sheets with non-negative polytropic indexes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14876v1.summary: Gravitational polarization is examined for equilibrium self-gravitating polytropic sheets perturbed by gravitational field due to test mass sheet. We find equilibrium solutions to the corresponding perturbed Lane-Emden equations. It is shown that gravitational vehementlypolarization may be observed even in a finite extent of self-Gravitatingsystems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14866v1.title: Imaging Molecular Outflow in Massive Star-forming Regions with HNCO Lines
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14866v1.summary: Protostellar outflows are considered a signpost of star formation. These outflows can cause shocks in the molecular gas and are typically traced by theline wings of certain molecules. HNCO (4--3) has been regarded as a shocktracer because of the high abundance in shocked regions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14786v1.title: Detecting Low-Mass Perturbers in Cluster Lenses using Curved Arc Bases
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14786v1.summary: Strong gravitationally lensed arcs and arclets in galaxy clusters have been observationally detected for several decades. This method offers the possibility of detecting individual low-mass perturber subhalos in clusters and halos along the line-of-sight. By allowing us to probe lower-mass substructure, the use of the curved arc bases can lead to powerful constraints on the nature of dark matter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14767v1.title: The $\textit{NuSTAR}$ Extragalactic Surveys: Source Catalogs from the Extended $\textit{Chandra}$ Deep Field-South and the $\textit{Chandra}$ Deep Field-North
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14767v1.summary: We present a routinized and reliable method to obtain source catalogs from the $Nuclear Spectroscopic Telescope Array. The method provides a systematic approach for source cataloging in other extragalactic surveys. We verify the reliability of our two catalogs by crossmatching them with the relevant X-ray catalogs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14766v1.title: Detection Rate of <50-meter Interstellar Objects with LSST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14766v1.summary: Future sky surveys with greater sensitivity will allow for more frequent detections of interstellar objects, including increasingly small objects. We estimate a detection rate of up to. small ISO every two years of LSST's operation with an increase by a factor of. of ten for future surveys that extend a magnitude deeper.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14567v1.title: Photometric classification of QSOs from ALHAMBRA survey using random forest
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14567v1.summary: Random Forests (RF) trained to classify quasars using magnitudes or colours. Best performances of the classifier yielded global accuracy and quasar precision around 0.9. Varying model free parameters has no significant effects on the final classification. Colours that contribute the most to the classification are those containing the near-infrared $JHK$ bands.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.00027v2.title: CEERS Key Paper IV: Galaxies at $4 < z < 9$ are Bluer than They Appear -- Characterizing Galaxy Stellar Populations from Rest-Frame $\sim 1$ micron Imaging
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.00027v2.summary: We present results from the Cosmic Evolution Early Release Survey (CEERS) on the stellar-population parameters for 28 galaxies with redshifts $4<z<9$ Using James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) Mid-Infrared Instrument (MIRI) combined with data from the Hubble Space Telescope and the Spitzer SpaceTelescope.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14518v1.title: The Past and Future of East Asia to Italy: Nearly Global VLBI
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14518v1.summary: The East Asia to Italy Nearly Global VLBI project is a collaboration between Korean, Japanese, and Italian researchers. Problems related to the very different arrays and technical details of thetelescopes involved are presented and discussed. The results have attracted international researchers and the collaboration is growing, now including Chinese and Russian stations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2204.01765v2.title: Self-regulated AGN feedback of light jets in cool-core galaxy clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2204.01765v2.summary: Heating from active galactic nuclei (AGN) is thought to stabilize cool-core clusters, limiting star formation and cooling flows. We employ radiative magicallymagneto-hydrodynamic (MHD) simulations to model light AGN jet feedback in a Perseus-like cluster. We find that increased jetefficiencies lead to more intermittent jet powers and enhanced star formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14394v1.title: MaNGA integral-field stellar kinematics of LoTSS radio galaxies: Luminous radio galaxies tend to be slow rotators
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14394v1.summary: The radio jets of an active galactic nucleus (AGN) can heat up the gas around a host galaxy and quench star formation activity. The presence of a radio jet could be related to the evolutionary path of the host galaxy. The jet may be imprinted in the morphology and kinematics of the galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2103.13932v3.title: QUOTAS: A new research platform for the data-driven investigation of black holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2103.13932v3.summary: We present QUOTAS, a novel research platform for the data-driven investigation of super-massive black hole (SMBH) populations. We assemble and co-locate the high-redshift, luminous quasarpopulation at $z \geq 3$ alongside simulated data of the same epochs. We conclude that sub-grid models of mass accretion and SMBH feedback implemented in Illustris-TNG300 do not reproduce their observed mass growth.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12165v2.title: X-Shooting ULLYSES: Massive stars at low metallicity. III. Terminal wind speeds of ULLYSES massive stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12165v2.summary: Winds of massive stars have an impact on stellar evolution and on the surrounding medium. The maximum speed reached by these outflows, the terminal wind speed, is a global wind parameter and an essential input for models of stellar atmospheres and feedback. We quantify the wind speeds of a large sample of OB stars, including supergiants, giants, and dwarfs at sub-solar metallicity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.12599v2.title: HOPS 361-C's Jet Decelerating and Precessing Through NGC 2071 IR
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.12599v2.summary: Proper motions for the brightest knots decrease from 350 to 100 km/s. The jet is embedded at a 1/5 to 4/5 fractional cloud depth. Measurements are matched with a precession period of 1,000--3,000 years and half opening angle of $15/.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.08831v3.title: Study of the Intermediate Mass Ratio Black Hole Binary Merger up to 1000:1 with Numerical Relativity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.08831v3.summary: Numerical techniques are used to predict gravitational waves from black hole mergers. This is relevant for future third generation (3G) gravitational wave detectors. The results of the study were published in the journal The Astrophysics of Gravitational Wave Theory and Theory of Relativity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02684v3.title: Rhapsody-C simulations -- Anisotropic thermal conduction, black hole physics, and the robustness of massive galaxy cluster scaling relations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02684v3.summary: We present the Rhapsody-C simulations of massive galaxy clusters. They include anisotropic thermal conduction, modified supermassive black hole feedback and new SMBH seeding and orbital decay models. We explore the parameter space of the models and report their effect on both star formation and the thermodynamics of the proto-cluster medium.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14239v1.title: Warm dark matter constraints from the JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14239v1.summary: Warm Dark Matter (WDM) particles offer an attractive solution to the small-scale issues faced by the Cold Dark Matter paradigm. WDM as light as 1.5 keV is already disfavoured by the low-mass end of the SMF. Forthcoming JWST observations of multiple blank fields can thus be used as a strong probe of WDM at an epoch inaccessible by other means.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14210v1.title: Disk settling and dynamical heating: histories of Milky Way-mass stellar disks across cosmic time in the FIRE simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14210v1.summary: We quantify the relative importance of cosmological disk settling andpost-formation dynamical heating. We identify three eras: a Pre-Disk Era, when stars formed on dispersion-dominated orbits. We compare the evolution of the three velocity components at all times. Young stars in FIRE-2 are kinematically hotter than the MW but broadly agree with M31 and M33.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14204v1.title: On the dearth of C-enhanced metal-poor stars in the Galactic bulge
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14204v1.summary: The Galactic bulge is predicted to host the oldest stellar fossils. A significant fraction of these fossils is represented by stars known as Carbon-Enhanced                Metal-Poor (CEMP) These CEMP stars are largelyobserved in the Galactic halo and ultra-faint dwarf galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14142v1.title: Early phases of the Galaxy from the chemical imprint on the iron-poor stars J0815+4729 and J0023+0307
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14142v1.summary: We have been exploring large spectroscopic databases such as SDSS to search for unique stars with extremely low iron content. We recently identified two extremely iron-poor dwarf stars J0815+4729 (Aguado et al. 2018a) and J0023+0307. We have also acquired high-resolution spectroscopy with UVES at 8.2mVLT telescope (Paranal, ESO, Chile) and HIRES at the 10m KeckI telescope (MaunaKea, Hawaii, USA)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14090v1.title: Physics-informed neural networks in the recreation of hydrodynamic simulations from dark matter
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14090v1.summary: Hydrodynamic simulations are a core constituent of modern cosmology. Physics-informed neural networks have emerged as a coherent framework for building predictive models. The underlying notion is to enrich the optimization loss function with known relationships to constrain the space of possible solutions. The results demonstrate improved accuracy of dark matter predictions based on dark matter halo properties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.03040v2.title: Massive prompt cusps: A new signature of warm dark matter
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.03040v2.summary: Every dark matter halo and subhalo is expected to have a prompt central density cusp. The sizes of these prompt cusps are linked to the scales of the peaks in the initial density field from which they formed. A prompt cusp's properties are highly sensitive to when it was formed, so prospects can be improved.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13205v2.title: A spectacular jet from the bright 244-440 Orion proplyd: the MUSE NFM view
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13205v2.summary: We present the highest spatial and spectral resolution integralfield observations to date of the bipolar jet from the Orion proplyd 244-440 using MUSE NFM. We observed a previously unreportedchain of six distinct knots in a roughly S-shaped pattern. Analysis of the FeII and NiII lines suggests jet densities on the order of 10^5cm.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13861v1.title: Implications of evaporative cooling by H$_2$ for 1I/`Oumuamua
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13861v1.summary: First interstellar object observed in our solar system, 1I/`Oumuamua, demonstrated several peculiar properties, including extreme elongation and non-gravitational acceleration. Bergner and Seligman (2023) proposed that evaporation of trapped H$_2$ created by cosmic rays (CRs) can explain the non-Gravitationalacceleration. However, their calculation of surface temperature ignored the crucial cooling effect of evaporating H$2$ from water ice.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.14323v2.title: Neural Stellar Population Synthesis Emulator for the DESI PROVABGS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.14323v2.summary: The Probabilistic Value-Added Bright Galaxy Survey (PROVABGS) catalog will provide the posterior distributions of physical properties of $>10$ million galaxies. Each posterior distribution will be inferred from joint Bayesian modeling of observed photometry and spectroscopy. To make this computationally feasible, the catalog will use a neural emulator for the SPS model to accelerate the inference.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13150v2.title: Modeling of thermal and non-thermal radio emission from HH80-81 jet
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13150v2.summary: Protostellar jets are one of the primary signposts of star formation. We characterize the radio spectra of the HH80-81 jet with the help of a numerical model. The model takes into account both thermal free-free and non-thermal synchrotron emission mechanisms.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.05186v3.title: Black hole and galaxy co-evolution in radio-loud AGN at z ~ 0.3-4
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.05186v3.summary: There exists a well known relation between the mass of the supermassive black hole (SMBH) in the center of galaxies and their bulge mass or central velocity. This suggests a co-evolution between SMBH and their galaxy hosts. Our aim is to study this relation specifically for radio loud galaxies, and as a function of redshift $z$.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13858v1.title: Unveiling the gravitationally unstable disc of a massive star-forming galaxy using NOEMA and MUSE
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13858v1.summary: The galaxy hosts a massive, clumpy disc and is a prototypical analogue of main-sequence galaxies at z~1-2.5. The study provides evidence that "in-situ" massive clump formation is very efficiently induced by large-scale instabilities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13822v1.title: Herbig-Haro Flows and Young Stars in the Dobashi 5006 Dark Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13822v1.summary: Two new Herbig-Haro flows were found in a study of the isolated Dobashi 5006 dark cloud. The newly discovered compact star-formation zone has an age of no more than a few million years and this process continues up to the present time. They are part of the poorly-located star cluster MWSC 0739.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.00305v2.title: Effects of galactic magnetic field on the UHECR correlation studies with starburst galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.00305v2.summary: We estimate the biases caused by the coherent deflection of cosmic rays due to the Galactic magnetic field (GMF) in maximum-likelihood analysis for ultrahigh-energy cosmic ray (UHECR) sources in the literature. We find the true parameters which are compatible with the best-fit parameters reported in (arXiv:1801.06160)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12769v2.title: Ensemble Mapping the Inner Structure of Luminous Quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12769v2.summary: A simple prediction of the well-known unification model of active galacticuclei is that a sample of sources should exhibit an anti-correlation between the solid angle of the dusty torus and of the ionization cone. For the first time, we detect a clear intrinsic anti-Correlation between them, which immediately verifies the torus/ionization-cone geometry in luminous quasars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13692v1.title: Predicting Physical Parameters of Cepheid and RR Lyrae variables in an Instant with Machine Learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13692v1.summary: Machine learning method to estimate the physical parameters of pulsating stars such as RR Lyrae and Cepheid variables. The fundamental parameters ofthese stars can be estimated up to 60 percent more accurately when the light curve parameters are taken into consideration. This method was applied to theobservations of hundreds of Cepheids and thousands of RR LyRAe in the Magellanic Clouds.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13689v1.title: Absorption Line Observations of H$_3^+$ and CO in Sight Lines Toward the Vela and W28 Supernova Remnants
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13689v1.summary: Supernova remnants act as particle accelerators, providing the cosmic-rayprotons that permeate the interstellar medium and initiate the ion-molecule reactions that drive interstellar chemistry. Enhanced fluxes of cosmic- rayprotons in close proximity to supernova remnants have been inferred from observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13676v1.title: Resolved stellar population properties of PHANGS-MUSE galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13676v1.summary: Analyzing resolved stellar populations across the disk of a galaxy can provide unique insights into how that galaxy assembled its stellar mass over its lifetime. In general, the derived assembly histories of the galaxies in our sample tell a consistent story of inside-out growth, where low-mass galaxies assembled the majority of their stellar mass later in cosmic history.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13640v1.title: Resonant instabilities mediated by drag and electrostatic interactions in laboratory and astrophysical dusty plasmas
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13640v1.summary: Dusty plasmas are known to support a diverse range of instabilities. This includes both generalizations of standard plasma instabilities and ones caused by effects specific to dusty systems. It has been recently demonstrated that a broad class of streaming instabilities, termed resonant draginstabilities, can be attributed to a particular resonance phenomenon.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.03702v2.title: Galaxy quenching timescales from a forensic reconstruction of their colour evolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.03702v2.summary: The timescales on which galaxies move out of the blue cloud to the red provide insight into the mechanisms drivingquenching. We build upon previous work, where we showcased a method to construct the colour evolution of observed low-redshift galaxies. After accounting for selection bias, we find evidence for anincrease in the colour of galaxies in GAMA as a function of cosmic time.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.09781v2.title: Anisotropic correlation functions as tracers of central galaxy alignments in simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.09781v2.summary: We use IllustrisTNG hydrodynamical simulations to study the alignment of the central galaxies in groups with the surrounding structures. This approach allows us to analyse galaxy and group properties not available in observations. Overall, our results reproduce observational ones, as we find large-scale anisotropy, which is dominated by the red central galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13586v1.title: Extragalactic magnetism with SOFIA (SALSA Legacy Program) -- V: First results on the magnetic field orientation of galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13586v1.summary: We present the analysis of the magnetic field ($B$-field) structure of                galaxies measured with far-infrared (FIR) and radio (3 and 6 cm) polarimetricobservations. We use the first data release of the Survey on extragALactic transformativemagnetiSm with SOFIA (SALSA) of 14 nearby ($<20$ Mpc) galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13575v1.title: LBT-MODS spectroscopy of high-redshift candidates in the Chandra J1030 field. A newly discovered z$\sim$2.8 large scale structure
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13575v1.summary: We present the results of a spectroscopic campaign with the Multi-Object                Double Spectrograph (MODS) instrument mounted on the Large Binocular Telescope. The campaign led to the discovery of a z~2.78 large scale structure (LSS) in the J1030field. The structure contains four X-ray sources and two non-X-ray detected galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13574v1.title: Quiescent low-mass galaxies observed by JWST in the Epoch of Reionization
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13574v1.summary: JWST discovery of a quiescent, low-mass galaxy at redshift $z=7.3$ (JADES-GS-z7-01-QU) represents a uniqueopportunity to study the imprint of feedback processes on early galaxyevolution. We build a sample of 130 low- mass galaxies from the SERRA cosmological zoom-in simulations, which show a feedback-regulated star formation history.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.03058v2.title: The $z \lesssim 1$ drop of cosmic dust abundance in a semi-analytic framework
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.03058v2.summary: The amount of galactic dust in the Universe appears to have decreased by a factor of $2-3$ during the last 8 Gyr. We use the semi-analytic model (SAM) L-Galaxies2020 to show that this drop may be reproduced. The model reproduces somefundamental properties of the local galaxy population.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.08206v2.title: The Outer spiral arm of the Milky Way using Red Clump stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.08206v2.summary: This is the first study to map the Outer arms across the disc using red clump stars. We have generated a face-on-view (XY-plane) of the Galaxy depicting the density distribution and count ratio above and below the Galactic plane. Apart from the spiral structures, we also see a wave-like asymmetry above andbelow the galactic plane with respect to longitudes indicating the warp structure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.10401v2.title: Diagnosing deceivingly cold dusty galaxies at 3.5<z<6: a substantial population of compact starbursts with high infrared optical depths
http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.10401v2.summary: Using NOEMA and ALMA 3mm line scans, we measure spectroscopic redshifts of six new dusty galaxies at 3.5<z<4.2. We conclude that these galaxies are deceivingly cold at the surface but actually warm in their starbursting cores. This work confirms the existence of a substantialpopulation of deceivingLY cold, compact dusty starburst galaxies at z>~4.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.09827v3.title: Line Emission Mapper (LEM): Probing the physics of cosmic ecosystems
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.09827v3.summary: The Line Emission Mapper (LEM) is an X-ray Probe for the 2030s. It will answer the outstanding questions of the Universe's structure formation. LEM will use a large microcalorimeter/IFU, covering a 30x30' field with 10" angular resolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.06189v2.title: Cosmological simulations of the same spiral galaxy: connecting the dark matter distribution of the host halo with the subgrid baryonic physics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.06189v2.summary: The role of baryonic physics, star formation, and stellar feedback, in shaping the galaxies and their host halos is an evolving topic. We focus on the halo morphology, geometry, and profile as well as the phase space distribution using one dark matter only and five high-resolution simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17516v1.title: Reference frames in General Relativity and the galactic rotation curves
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17516v1.summary: We discuss the extension of the International Astronomical Union (IAU) reference system to the exact theory. We debunk the so-called Balasin-Grumiller (BG) model, and the claims that the rotation curves of galaxies can be explained through gravitomagnetic effects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17488v1.title: An investigation of the circumgalactic medium around z~2.2 AGN with ACA and ALMA
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17488v1.summary: Recent observations of galaxies and quasars at high redshift (z>2) have revealed evidence for cold gaseous halos of scale r_CGM~10kpc. We present deep ACA and ALMA observations of CO(3-2) from this source and two other quasar host galaxies at z~2.2. While we find evidence for CO emission on scales of r~10Kpc, we do not find evidence of massive molecular gas on scales larger than r>20 kpc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17484v1.title: A cosmic stream of atomic carbon gas connected to a massive radio galaxy at redshift 3.8
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17484v1.summary: The growth of galaxies in the early Universe is driven by accretion ofCircum- and inter-galactic gas. Simulations predict that steady streams of cold gas penetrate the dark matter halos of galaxies, providing the raw materialnecessary to sustain star formation. We report a filamentary stream of gas that extends for 100 kiloparsecs and connects to the massive radio galaxy 4C 41.17.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17473v1.title: A hard look at the X-ray spectral variability of NGC 7582
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17473v1.summary: NGC 7582 (z = 0.005264; D = 22.5 Mpc) is a highly variable, changing-look AGN. The column density of the absorber in the line of sight varies from Compton-thin to Compton-thick. The results are consistent with comet-like obscuring clouds.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17424v1.title: A novel survey for young substellar objects with the W-band filter VI: Spectroscopic census of sub-stellar members and the IMF of $σ$ Orionis cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17424v1.summary: Low-mass stars and sub-stellar objects are essential in tracing the initial                mass function (IMF) We study the nearby young Orionis cluster using deep NIR photometric data in J, W and H-bands from WIRCam on the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope. We find that a two-segment power-law fits the sub- stellar autoimmuneIMF better than the log-normal distribution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2205.11767v3.title: Charting Galactic Accelerations with Stellar Streams and Machine Learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2205.11767v3.summary: We present a data-driven method for reconstructing the galactic acceleration field from phase-space measurements of stellar streams. Our approach is based on a flexible and differentiable fit to the stream in phase- space. We find our method recovers the correct parameters for a ground-truth triaxial logarithmic halo potential.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17406v1.title: Constraining the Gravitational Potential from the Projected Morphology of Extragalactic Tidal Streams
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17406v1.summary: The positions and velocities of stellar streams have been used to constrain the mass and shape of the Milky Way's dark matter halo. We present a fast method to infer halo shapes from the curvature of 2D projected stream tracks. We apply our method to low surface brightness imaging of NGC autoimmune5907, and find that its dark Matter halo is oblate.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17341v1.title: On the impact of $f(Q)$ gravity on the Large Scale Structure
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17341v1.summary: We investigate the exponential $f(Q)$ symmetric teleparallel gravitation. To reproduce viable cosmology, we first perform Markov horriblyChain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling on OHD/BAO/Pantheon datasets. While carrying out N-body+SPH simulations, we derive CDM+baryons, matter power spectrum, bispectrum, two-point correlation function and halo mass function.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10868v2.title: 3D Radiation Hydrodynamic Simulations of Gravitational Instability in AGN Accretion Disks: Effects of Radiation Pressure
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10868v2.summary: We perform 3D radiation hydrodynamic local shearing box simulations to study gravitational instability (GI) in optically thick ActiveGalactic Nuclei (AGN) accretion disks. GI develops when the Toomre parameter QT\leq 1, and may lead to turbulent heating that balances radiative cooling.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2010.01151v3.title: High resolution study of outflows and chemical environment of First Hydrostatic Core candidate Chamaeleon-MMS1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2010.01151v3.summary: The earliest stages of low-mass star-formation are unclear, but it has been proposed that Chamaeleon-MMS1 is a candidate First Hydrostatic Core. This workdescribes the local (~4000 AU) outflow activity associated with the source and its effect on the surrounding material in order to determine the evolutionary state of the source.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17282v1.title: Diagnosis of 3D magnetic field and modes composition in MHD turbulence with Y-parameter
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17282v1.summary: The determination of magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) turbulence and 3Dmagnetic field properties in ISM is notoriously difficult. We found that the anisotropy of Stokes parameters can act as a diagnostic for retrieving the 3D magnetic field inclination and identifying dominating mode. As a consequence, in the future with the availability of radio polarisation surveys, this technique can play a leading role in discovering the nature of the interstellar turbulence.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17246v1.title: Sub-Millimetre Galaxies with Webb: Near-Infrared Counterparts and Multi-wavelength Morphology
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17246v1.summary: We identify 45 SCUBA-2 SMG positions within The Cosmic Evolution Early Release Science Survey (CEERS) JWST/NIRCamfields. We analyse their rest-frame optical and near-infrared morphological properties. Using EaZy-py we fit the available observations to quantify the photometric redshifts of the NIRCam-SMGs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.10464v2.title: Determination of the angular momentum of the Kerr black hole from equatorial geodesic motion
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.10464v2.summary: We present a method to determine the angular momentum of a black hole. The method is based on observations of the trajectories of the bodies in the Kerr space-time. We tailor a numerical code to resolve the dynamical equations and use it to generate synthetic data. We apply the method in some representative examples.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17133v1.title: Classifying a frequently repeating fast radio burst, FRB 20201124A, with unsupervised machine learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17133v1.summary: Fast radio bursts (FRBs) are astronomical transients with millisecond timescales. Most of the FRBs are not observed to repeat, but a few have been detected to repeat more than hundreds of times. There exist a large variety of physical properties among these bursts, suggesting heterogeneous mechanisms.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14767v2.title: The $\textit{NuSTAR}$ Extragalactic Surveys: Source Catalogs from the Extended $\textit{Chandra}$ Deep Field-South and the $\textit{Chandra}$ Deep Field-North
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14767v2.summary: We present a routinized and reliable method to obtain source catalogs from the $Nuclear Spectroscopic Telescope Array. The method provides a systematic approach for source cataloging in other extragalactic surveys. We verify the reliability of our two catalogs by crossmatching them with the relevant X-ray catalogs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.05131v2.title: Toward Horizon-scale Accretion Onto Supermassive Black Holes in Elliptical Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.05131v2.summary: We present high-resolution, three-dimensional hydrodynamic simulations of thefueling of supermassive black holes in elliptical galaxies. The key physical ingredients are radiative cooling and aphenomenological heating model. We find that the accretion flow takes the form of multiphase gas at radii less than about a kpc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17095v1.title: Small scale clustering of BOSS galaxies: dependence on luminosity, color, age, stellar mass, specific star formation rate and other properties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17095v1.summary: We measure and analyze galaxy clustering and the dependence on luminosity, color, age, stellar mass and specific star formation rate. We find that the clustering dependence is consistent with previous well-established results showing the broad trends in galaxy formation. We also investigate the dependence of other parameters previously derived from stellar population synthesis models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17067v1.title: On the computation of interstellar extinction in photoionized nebulae
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17067v1.summary: Ueta & Otsuka (2021) proposed a method to analyze spectroscopic data of ionized nebulae. The authors reanalyzed the results of Galera-Rosillo et al. (2022, GR22) on nine of the brightest planetary ne Bulae in M31. They claim that, if standard values of the physical conditions are used to compute the extinction instead of their proposed method, extinction correction is underestimated by more than 50%.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17035v1.title: On The Planetary Theory of Everything
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17035v1.summary: We show that "galaxy" formation, dark matter, and the tension in the expansion of the universe can all be explained by the natural behaviors of an overwhelmingly large population of exoplanets. Some of these ideas have started to be proposed in the literature, and we commend these pioneers for revolutionizing our understanding of astrophysics. We assert that, since planets are obviously the ubiquitous answer to every current question, planetary science must then be the basis for all science.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17002v1.title: Galaxy Evolution in $\ddotμ$ based Cosmologies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17002v1.summary: JWST observations of massive galaxies atextremely high redshifts are consistent with such a cosmology. But the low redshift Universe is entirely divergent from the cosmic starformation rate density. We propose that our Universe was at one pointdominated by a Primordial Bovine Herd (PBH) which later decayed producing dark energy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.11911v2.title: A Flat-Spectrum Radio Transient at 122 Mpc consistent with an Emerging Pulsar Wind Nebula
http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.11911v2.summary: VT 1137-0337 is located in the brightest region of a dwarf starburst galaxy. Its 3 GHz luminosity is comparable to luminous radio supernovae associated with circumstellar interaction and relativistic outflows. Its featureless power law cannot be directly explained by the shock of a stellar explosion. Instead, we propose that the nebula is a decades old pulsarwind nebula.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16977v1.title: Evidence of a Decreased Binary Fraction for Massive Stars Within 20 Milliparsecs of the Supermassive Black Hole at the Galactic Center
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16977v1.summary: First systematic search for spectroscopic.binaries within the central 2 x 3 arcsec$^2$ around the supermassive black hole. Based on over a decade of adaptive optics-fed integral-field spectroscopy (R$\sim$4000), obtained as part of the Galactic Center Orbits Initiative.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16941v1.title: When Tails Tell Tales
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16941v1.summary: The enigmatic open clusters serve as a constant reminder of the mysteries of the universe, helping to confront astronomical theories. I present a succinct survey of this subject matter, detailing the intrepid efforts of astronomers. I offer a novel proposal for their nomenclature, while not disregarding the philosophical ramifications.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16937v1.title: Don't believe the hype(r): The Yellow Supergiants of Westerlund 1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16937v1.summary: Yellow hypergiants (YHGs) are often presumed to represent a transitional post-red supergiant (RSG) phase. We present the spectra of six YHG candidates in the Galactic cluster Westerlund 1. The population of YSGs in Wd1 is very unusual, with YHGs outnumbering RSGs, but with both spanning a large luminosity range.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16934v1.title: Carbon stars as standard candles -- III. Un-binned maximum likelihood fitting and comparison with TRGB estimations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16934v1.summary: In the second paper of this series, we developed a new distance determinationmethod using the median $J$ magnitude of carbon-rich asymptotic giant branch stars. The new fitting method uses an un-binned maximum likelihood estimator to determine the parameters of the Lorentzian model resulting in parameter errors that are significantly smaller.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16933v1.title: MUSEQuBES: Mapping the distribution of neutral hydrogen around low-redshift galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16933v1.summary: The galaxies are selected from our MUSEQuBES low-z survey along with data from the literature. They are probed by 184 background quasars giving rise to 5054 quasar-galaxy pairs. The median stacked profile for the full sample can be explained by a galaxy-absorber two-point correlation function with r0 = 6.7 pMpc and gamma = 1.57.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16927v1.title: The correlation between the average density of circumnuclear molecular gas and AGN activity for massive elliptical galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16927v1.summary: Mass of the molecular gas within a fixed radius (500 pc) from the galactic nucleus (AGN) is correlated with the jet power estimated from X-ray cavities. The massaccretion rate of the circumnuclear gas also has a correlation with P_cav. The origin of the continuum emission from the AGNs at 100-300 ~GHz is mostly synchrotron radiation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1904.02673v3.title: A Surprising Lack of Metallicity Evolution with Redshift in the Long Gamma-Ray Burst Host Galaxy Population
http://arxiv.org/abs/1904.02673v3.summary: The number of long-duration Gamma Ray Burst (LGRB) host galaxies with measured metallicities and host masses has now grown to over one hundred. The fraction of LGRB hosts with relatively high metallicity remains essentially constant out to z = 2.5. This is at odds with the evolution in the mass-metallicity relation of typical galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16925v1.title: The Bactrian? Broad-lined Type-Ic supernova SN 2022xxf with extraordinary two-humped light curves
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16925v1.summary: We report on our study of SN 2022xxf during the first four months of its evolving. The light curves (LCs) display two humps at similar maximum brightness separated by 75d, unprecedented for a broad-lined Type Ic supernova. We propose that theradiative energy from the ejecta-CSM interaction is a plausible explanation for the second LC hump.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16920v1.title: On the impact of spectral template uncertainties in synthetic stellar populations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16920v1.summary: Uncertainties in stellar population models translate into uncertainties in ourinterpretation of stellar populations in galaxies. Observations by JWST are revealing high-redshift galaxies in great detail, which must then be compared to models. Predictions for spectral line indices can vary significantly, with equivalent widths differing by a factor of two in some cases.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.18245v1.title: AGN in the CALIFA survey: X-ray detection of nuclear sources
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.18245v1.summary: Optical surveys estimate the population of AGN in the local Universe to be of 4%. We find 34 new bonafide AGN and 23 AGN candidates, which could increase the AGN population to 7-10%. X-rays are particularly helpful for low-luminosity AGN since they are excluded by the criterion of large diameter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.18229v1.title: Supermassive black hole mass in the massive elliptical galaxy M87 from integral-field stellar dynamics using OASIS and MUSE with adaptive optics: assessing systematic uncertainties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.18229v1.summary: The massive elliptical galaxy M87 has been the subject of several.supermassive black hole mass measurements from stellar dynamics, gas. and recently the black hole shadow by the Event Horizon Telescope (EHT) Thisuniquely positions M87 as a benchmark for alternative black. hole massdetermination methods.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.18198v1.title: The saturation mechanism of thermal instability
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.18198v1.summary: The nonlinear outcome of plasma instabilities range from a gentlereconfiguration of the initial state to an explosive one. We show that both the contraction rebound event and the subsequent pulsation behavior follow analytically from an analysis of the newidentities. We also show that even for a simplehomogeneous plasma, all these possibilities can occur, depending on whether the condensation is isobaric or nonisobaric.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.13250v2.title: Molecular gas and star formation in nearby starburst galaxy mergers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.13250v2.summary: We employ the Feedback In Realistic Environments (FIRE-2) physics model to study how the properties of giant molecular clouds (GMCs) evolve during galaxy mergers. We find that the gasdepletion time is significantly lower for high GMCs during a starburst event. This is in contrast to the simple physical picture that low GMCs are easier to collapse and form stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.18123v1.title: Globular Clusters in the Galactic Center Region: expected behavior in the infalling and merger scenario
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.18123v1.summary: The infall and merger scenario of massive clusters in the Milky Way's potential well is reexamined to understand how the stars of the merging clusters are redistributed during andafter the merger process. We used simulations with a highresolution concentrated in the 300 pc around the Galactic center. We detect that the least massive clusters are quickly destroyed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09087v2.title: Metal line emission from galaxy haloes at z~1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09087v2.summary: We present a study of the metal-enriched halo gas, traced using MgII and [OII] emission lines, in two large, blind galaxy surveys. By stacking a sample of ~600 galaxies, we characterize for the first time the average metal line                emission from a general population of galaxy haloes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.18076v1.title: Machine learning applications for the study of AGN physical properties using photometric observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.18076v1.summary: We investigate the physical nature of Active Galactic Nuclei using machine learning tools. A Support Vector Regression (SVR) ML-model is trained on spectroscopically observed AGN from the SPIDERS-AGN survey. We present the reconstructed catalogue of 21364AGN with redshifts ranging from $ 0 < z < 2.5$.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.18053v1.title: The Local Cluster Survey II: Disk-Dominated Cluster Galaxies with Suppressed Star Formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.18053v1.summary: We investigate the role of dense environments in suppressing star formation. We find that the degree of SFR suppression increases with increasingbulge-to-total (B/T) ratio. In addition, the SFRs of cluster and infall                galaxies at a fixed mass are more suppressed than their field counterparts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.18040v1.title: Investigating the amplitude and rotation of the phase spiral in the Milky Way outer disc
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.18040v1.summary: Aims to characterize the shape, rotation, amplitude, and metallicity of the phase spiral in the outer disc of the Milky Way. This will allow us to better understand which physical processes caused the spiral and give further clues to its past and current state. We use Gaia data release 3 (DR3) to get full position and velocity data on approximately 31.5 million stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.18009v1.title: Could compact stars in globular clusters constrain dark matter?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.18009v1.summary: The dark matter content of globular clusters, highly compact gravity-boundstellar systems, is unknown. It is also generally unknow*able*, due to their mass-to-light ratios typically ranging between 1$-$3 in solar units. Recent claims in the literature assume densities of dark matter around 1000 GeV/cm$^3$ to set constraints on its capture and annihilation in white dwarfs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.07008v2.title: The Galactic Center as a laboratory for theories of gravity and dark matter
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.07008v2.summary: The Galactic Center of the Milky Way allows to investigate physical phenomena at the edge of astrophysics and fundamental physics. It offers a unique laboratory to probe gravity, where one can not only test the basic predictions of General Relativity, but is also able to falsify theories that, over time, have been proposed to modify or extend the theory.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17980v1.title: Interstellar Objects and Exocomets
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17980v1.summary: In this chapter we review our knowledge of our galaxy's cometary population outside our Oort Cloud. Exocomets and Interstellar Objects (ISOs) are discussed. The discovery of the first two ISOs is then described, along with the surprising differences in their observed characteristics. We end by looking ahead to what advances may take place in the next decade.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12590v2.title: Unveiling the chemical fingerprint of phosphorus-rich stars I. In the infrared region of APOGEE-2
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12590v2.summary: The origin of phosphorus, one of the essential elements for life on Earth, is currently unknown. Prevalent models of Galactic chemical evolution (GCE) grossly underestimate the amount of P compared to observations. The recently discovered P-rich and metal-poor giants further challenge current theories on stellar nucleosynthesis.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15499v2.title: Mother of Dragons: A Massive, quiescent core in the dragon cloud (IRDC G028.37+00.07)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15499v2.summary: A massive core in the well-studied infrared-darkcloud (IRDC) called the 'dragon cloud' is analysed. The cores are very dense and have only trans-sonic non-thermal motions. This suggests the cores are gravitationally unstable, unless supported by magnetic fields with strengths of 1 - 10 mG.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17133v2.title: Classifying a frequently repeating fast radio burst, FRB 20201124A, with unsupervised machine learning
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17133v2.summary: Fast radio bursts (FRBs) are astronomical transients with millisecond timescales. Most of the FRBs are not observed to repeat, but a few have been detected to repeat more than hundreds of times. There exist a large variety of physical properties among these bursts, suggesting heterogeneous mechanisms.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.04731v2.title: A Glimpse of the Stellar Populations and Elemental Abundances of Gravitationally Lensed, Quiescent Galaxies at $z\gtrsim 1$ with Keck Deep Spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.04731v2.summary: Two lensed, quiescent galaxies at $z\gtrsim 1$ were discovered by the ASTRO 3DGalaxy Evolution with Lenses survey. We measured the age, [Fe/H], and [Mg/Fe] of the two galaxies using deep, rest-frame-optical spectra (S/N) obtained on the Keck~I telescope. Compared to nearby nearby galaxies of similar masses, the lensed galaxies have lower [ Fe/H] and [mg/H].

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.09614v2.title: Point-like sources among z>11 galaxy candidates: contaminants due to supernovae at high redshifts?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.09614v2.summary: Recent searches for z>11 galaxies using the James Webb Space Telescope have resulted in an unexpectedly high number of candidate objects. A question has risen whether there are some new types of contaminants among these candidates. We hypothesize that the point-source-dropouts could be supernovae at high redshifts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17759v1.title: Classical Novae in the ASKAP Pilot Surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17759v1.summary: We present a systematic search for radio counterparts of novae using the Australian Square Kilometer Array Pathfinder. We found radio counterparts for four novae: V5668 Sgr, V1369 Cen, YZ Ret, and RRTel. Follow-up observations with the Australian Telescope Compact Array confirm ejecta thinning across all observed bands.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17738v1.title: Estimating the selection function of Gaia DR3 sub-samples
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17738v1.summary: We aim to develop a methodology to estimate the selection function for different sub-samples of Gaia stars. Comparing the number of stars in a given sub-sample to those in the overall Gaia catalogue, provides an estimate of thesub-sample membership probability. This estimate must differentiate the stochastic absence of sub- sample stars from selection effects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2205.04273v2.title: Diffstar: A Fully Parametric Physical Model for Galaxy Assembly History
http://arxiv.org/abs/2205.04273v2.summary: We present Diffstar, a smooth parametric model for the in-situ star formation history of galaxies. Diffstar is distinct from conventional SFH models that are used to interpret the spectral energy distribution (SED) of an observing galaxy. The Diffstar model assumes that starformation is fueled by the accretion of gas into the dark matter halo of the galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2205.00857v2.title: Importance of intracluster scattering and relativistic corrections from tSZ effect with Cosmic Infrared Background
http://arxiv.org/abs/2205.00857v2.summary: The Sunyaev-Zeldovich effect towards clusters of galaxies has become astandard probe of cosmology. It is caused by the scattering of photons from thecosmic microwave background (CMB) by the hot cluster electron gas. In a similar manner, other photon backgrounds can be scattered when passing through the Cluster medium. This problem has been recently considered for the radio and the cosmic infrared background.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.12985v2.title: Revisiting secondary CMB distortions due to kinetic Sunyaev-Zel'dovich effect from quasar bubbles before reionization
http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.12985v2.summary: We discuss the secondary cosmic microwave background (CMB) anisotropy due to the Sunyaev-Zel'dovich (kSZ) effect from ionized bubbles around individualquasars prior to the reionization of the Universe. Next, we look at the imprint of a single quasar bubble on the CMB and show that it can be detected in a high-resolution, ambitious effort like CMB-HD.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17676v1.title: 188,000 Candidate Very Metal-poor Stars in Gaia DR3 XP Spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17676v1.summary: Very metal-poor stars in the Milky Way are fossil records of early chemical evolution and the assembly and structure of the Galaxy. Gaia DR3 has provided over 200 million low-resolution (R = 50) XP spectra. We utilise the XGBoost classification algorithm to identify about 188,000 very metal- poor star candidates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17673v1.title: The relation of metal-poor stars to nearby solar analogues
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17673v1.summary: Sun-like dwarf stars in the solar neighborhood reflect ages, an ``average''chemical evolution, and departures from that average. Four groups of Sunlike dwarfs form a continuum related to age. We compare the kinematic properties of these four groups with those of two sets of ultra metal-poor stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.10790v2.title: Nitrogen-enriched, highly-pressurized nebular clouds surrounding a super star cluster at cosmic noon
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.10790v2.summary: The Sunburst Arc, a lensed Cosmic Noon galaxy, hosts a young super star cluster. Strong lensing offers a precious opportunity for studying the formation andearly evolution of super star clusters that are rare in our cosmic backyard. We suggest a physical origin of the high-pressure clouds from partial or complete condensation of slow massive starjecta.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17638v1.title: Investigating physical states of molecular gas in the overlapping region of interacting galaxies NGC4567/4568 using ALMA
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17638v1.summary: ALMA observations of a diffuse gas tracer, CO(J = 1-0), and a warmer and denser gas trater, CO (J = 3-2), in the overlapping region of interacting galaxies NGC 4567/4568. The R3-2/1-0 of the molecular clouds in the filament is lower than that of the surrounding area.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17637v1.title: Chromaticity Effects on the Outcomes of Spheroid-based Scored Events
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17637v1.summary: The popularity of spheroid-based scored events motivates the desire to better understand the underlyingMechanisms affecting their outcomes. We investigate chromatic effects on the outcome of such events. We do this by finding the correlation between the color contrast and the success of several key sp heroidal ball match tactics.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17632v1.title: Boosting Line Intensity Map Signal-to-Noise with the Ly-$α$ Forest Cross-Correlation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17632v1.summary: We show that CO$\times$Ly-$\alpha$ forest can significantly enhance the detection signal-to-noise ratio of CO. We forecast the prospects for cross-correlating future line intensity mapping surveys with the current and future Ly-$\ alpha$ forest data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17626v1.title: Nuggets of Wisdom: Determining an Upper Limit on the Number Density of Chickens in the Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17626v1.summary: The lower limit on the chicken density function (CDF) of the observableUniverse was recently determined to be approximately 10$^{-21}$ chickens. For over a year, however, the scientific community has struggled to determine the upper limit to the CDF. We take aholistic approach to considering the effects of a high CDF in various domains.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17624v1.title: A First Look at Spatially Resolved Balmer Decrements at $1.0<z<2.4$ from JWST NIRISS Slitless Spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17624v1.summary: We present the first results on the spatial distribution of dust attenuation at $1.0<z<2.4$ traced by the Balmer Decrement. We model the typical light profiles of star-forming galaxies at these redshifts and stellarmasses with GALFIT. The total dust obscuration is mild.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17620v1.title: Exploring Thousands of Nearby Hierarchical Systems with Gaia and Speckle Interferometry
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.17620v1.summary: There should be about 10,000 stellar hierarchical systems within 100 pc with primary stars more massive than 0.5 Msun. A list of 8000 candidate multiples is derived from wide binaries found in the Gaia Catalog of Nearby Stars where one or both components have excessive astrometric noise or other indicators of inner subsystems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12577v2.title: Detection of Dust in High-Velocity Cloud Complex C -- Enriched Gas Accreting onto the Milky Way
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12577v2.summary: We present the detection of dust depletion in Complex C, a massive, plummeting, low-metallicity high-velocity cloud in the northern Galactichemisphere. We analyze a very high signal-to-noise HST/COS spectrum of AGN Mrk 817 formed by adding 165 individual exposures taken under the AGN STORM 2 program.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02581v1.title: M-sigma relations across space and time
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02581v1.summary: Feedback from active galactic nuclei (AGN) has long been invoked to explain correlation between black hole mass and stellar velocity dispersion. We show how jetted and non-jetted AGN parallel the path found by Sahu et al. (2019) The prediction is that thestrongest AGN feedback on stellar dispersion is a late universe phenomenon.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02503v1.title: On the correct computation of all Lyapunov exponents in Hamiltonian dynamical systems
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02503v1.summary: The Lyapunov Characteristic Exponents are a useful indicator of chaos in tumultuous dynamical systems. They are usually computed through a standard, very efficient and neat algorithm published in 1980. However, for Hamiltoniansystems the expected result of pairs of opposite exponents is not always obtained with enough precision.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02499v1.title: Discovery of the lensed quasar eRASS1 J050129.5-073309 with $\textit{SRG}/$eROSITA and ${\it Gaia}$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02499v1.summary: ERASS1 J050129.5-073309 at redshift $z=2.47$, selected from the first all-sky survey of the eROSITA telescope. The two images are separated by $2.7''$ and their average magnitudes are 16.95 and 17.33. Archival optical light curves show evidence of a time delay with the fainter component lagging the brighter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02494v1.title: The bright end of the galaxy luminosity function at $z \simeq 7$ from the VISTA VIDEO survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02494v1.summary: We have conducted a search for Lyman break galaxies over 8.2 square degrees of near-infrared imaging from the VISTA Deep ExtragalacticObservations survey. Candidate galaxies were selected from a full photometric redshift analysis down to a $Y+J$ depth of 25.3. We find that the inclusion of $YJHK_{s}$ photometry is vital for removing brown-dwarfcontaminants.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02463v1.title: The Next Generation Event Horizon Telescope Collaboration: History, Philosophy, and Culture
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02463v1.summary: This white paper outlines the plans of the History Philosophy Culture WorkingGroup of the Next Generation Event Horizon Telescope Collaboration. It was written by the History and Philosophy Working Group of the University of California, Los Angeles. The white paper was published by The History & Philosophy WorkingGroup on November 6, 2013.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02452v1.title: Abundances of CNO elements in z ~ 0.3-0.4 LyC leaking galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02452v1.summary: We present observations with the Space Telescope Imaging Spectrograph (STIS) on board the Hubble Space Telescope of eleven Lyman continuum (LyC) leaking galaxies at redshifts, z. We find that log(C/O) slightly decreases with increasing Mstar from -0.65 at Mstar=10^6 Msun to  0.80 at M star=10+10. The origin of these trends remains basically unknown.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02450v1.title: A Tale of 3 Dwarfs: No Extreme Cluster Formation in Extreme Star-Forming Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02450v1.summary: The three blue compact dwarf galaxies ESO185-IG13, ESO338-IG04, and Haro11 have some of the highest known SigmaSFR and published Gamma values. We present new estimates of Gamma for these BCDs in three age intervals (1-10 Myr, 10-100 Myr, 100-400 Myr) We find no evidence that Gamma increases with SigmaS FR.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12500v2.title: The first stars: formation, properties, and impact
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12500v2.summary: The first generation of stars, often called Population III (or Pop III), form from metal-free primordial gas at redshifts 30 and below. We review currentoretical models for the formation, properties and impact of Pop III stars, and discuss existing and future observational constraints.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02311v1.title: Milky Way globular clusters on cosmological timescales. II. Interaction with the Galactic centre
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02311v1.summary: We simulated the orbits of 147 globular clusters over 10 Gyr time using the parallel N-body code phi-GPU. We obtained 3-4 globular cluster interactions per Gyr at distances of less than 50 pc. We selected 10 of them for detailed study and found almost 100% probability of interaction with the Galactic centre for six of them.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.07002v2.title: Filament collapse: a two phase process
http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.07002v2.summary: Using numerical simulations, we investigate the gravitational evolution of molecular cloud structures and their condensation into denseprotostellar cores. One possible process is the so called 'edge effect', the pile-up of matter at the end of the filament due to self-gravity. This effect is predicted by theory but only rarely observed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02236v1.title: Identifying and characterizing ultracool dwarfs ejected from post-encounter disintegrating systems
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02236v1.summary: Disintegrating multiple systems have been previously discovered fromkinematic studies of the $\it Hipparcos$ catalogue. They are presumably the result of dynamical encounters taking place in the Galactic disk between single/multiple systems. We aim to study their properties, as well as to characterize possible low-mass ejecta (i.e. brown dwarfs and planets)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02227v1.title: On the origin of the split main sequences of the young massive cluster NGC 1856
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02227v1.summary: The young massive cluster NGC 1856 exhibits an apparent MS bifurcation. The number of tidally-locked binaries cannot account for the observation. The long-term evolution of star clusters can produce the observed split MSs, according to the authors of the study.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02209v1.title: Enlightening the dynamical evolution of Galactic open clusters: an approach using Gaia DR3 and analytical descriptions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02209v1.summary: Most stars in our Galaxy form in stellar aggregates, which can become long-lived structures called open clusters (OCs) Along their dynamicalevolution, their gradual depletion leave some imprints on their structure. In this work, we employed astrometric, photometric and spectroscopic data from the Gaia DR3 catalogue to uniformly characterize a sample of 60 OCs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.09220v2.title: QCD Axion and the Supermassive Black Holes at high $z$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.09220v2.summary: Axion dark matter (DM) is studied on the formation of supermassive blackholes (SMBHs) at high $z$. It is shown that the attractive self interaction of DM may solve the tension between the high angular momentum and the early time formation of SMBH. This fact may serve to specify a model among various models of dark matter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02196v1.title: Simulation of CSSTs astrometric capability
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02196v1.summary: The China Space Station Telescope (CSST) will enter a low Earth orbit around 2024 and operate for 10 years. To maximize the scientific output of CSST, it is important to optimize the survey schedule. We find that the accuracy of parallax and proper motion of CS ST is better than 1 mas( yr1) for sources of 18-22 mag in g band.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02142v1.title: Gemini Near Infrared Spectrograph - Distant Quasar Survey: Prescriptions for Calibrating UV-Based Estimates of Supermassive Black Hole Masses in High-Redshift Quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02142v1.summary: The most reliable single-epoch supermassive black hole mass estimates in quasars are obtained by using the velocity widths of low-ionization emission lines. We find that employing the equivalent width of C IV and Mg II provides values that are closest to those obtained from H$\beta. We also provide prescriptions to provide more accurate and precise estimates of $M_{\rm BH}$ given a much larger sample of qu asars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02123v1.title: Using Elliptical Galaxy Kinematics to Compare of the Strength of Gravity in Cosmological Regions of Differing Gravitational Potential -- A First Look
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02123v1.summary: We have compared the observed properties of luminous red galaxies inside and outside of voids in the cosmic large scale structure. We obtained a null result, with an upper limit on any fractional difference in G between the two samples. This upper bound is dominated by the small-number statistics of our N within-void LRG sample. We estimate that a 1\% statistical limit on $\alpha$ could be attained with data from 10 elliptical galaxies within voids.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02096v1.title: The CAMELS project: Expanding the galaxy formation model space with new ASTRID and 28-parameter TNG and SIMBA suites
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02096v1.summary: CAMELS-ASTRID is the third suite of hydrodynamical simulations in the Cosmology and Astrophysics with MachinE Learning project. It contains 2,124 hydrodynamic simulation runs that vary 3 cosmological parameters and 4 parameters controlling stellar and AGN feedback. The training set of ASTRID covers a broader variation in the variation in galaxy populations and the baryonic impact on the matter power spectrum than the TNG and SIMBA suites.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02085v1.title: Infrared spectroscopic confirmation of z~2 photometrically-selected obscured quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02085v1.summary: The census of obscured quasar populations is incomplete. The identification of previously undetected red, obscured high-redshiftquasar candidates suggests that there are more obscured quasars yet to be discovered. We present Gemini GNIRS near-infrared spectroscopy of 24 luminous obscured quaser candidates from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02066v1.title: Direct formation of massive black holes via dynamical collapse in metal-enriched merging galaxies at $z \sim 10$: fully cosmological simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02066v1.summary: We show that the merger of two massive galaxies at redshift $z \sim 8$ results in theformation of a nuclear supermassive disk (SMD) of only $4$ pc in radius. The core of the merger remnant is metal-rich, well above solar abundance, and the SMD reaches a gaseous mass of $3 \times 10^8$ $M_{\odot}$ in less than a million years after the merger.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02059v1.title: Can Protostellar Outflows Set Stellar Masses?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02059v1.summary: The opening angles of some protostellar outflows appear too narrow to match the expected core-star mass efficiency SFE = 0.3-0.5. Outflow cavities with paraboloidal shape and wider angles are more consistent with observed estimates of the SFE. This paper presents a model of infall and outflow evolution based on these properties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02054v1.title: The First Weak-lensing Analysis with the James Webb Space Telescope: SMACS J0723.3-7327
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02054v1.summary: Using the James Webb Space Telescope Early Release NIRCam Observations, we perform a weak-lensing analysis of a massive galaxy cluster. The mass distribution is found to elongate in the east-west direction with an extension to the northeast edge of the field of view. We hypothesize that SMACSJ0723 is observed near first                pericenter passage and we identify candidate radio relics.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02041v1.title: The SUPERCOLD-CGM survey: \\ I. Probing the extended CO(4-3) Emission of the Circumglactic medium in a sample of 10 Enormous Ly$α$ Nebulae at $z\sim2$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02041v1.summary: The coldest phase of thecircum-galactic medium (CGM) is directly linked to stellar growth. We present ALMA+ACA observations of CO(4-3) and continuum emission from 10 Enormous Ly$\alpha$ Nebula (ELANe) around ultraluminous type-I QSOs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02038v1.title: Measuring the photo-ionization rate, neutral fraction and mean free path of HI ionizing photons at $4.9 \leq z \leq 6.0$ from a large sample of XShooter and ESI spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02038v1.summary: We measure the mean free path, photo-ionization rate and neutral fraction of hydrogen in 12 redshift bins at $4.85<z<6.05$ from a large sample of moderate resolution XShooter and ESI QSO absorption spectra. The simulations show remarkable agreement with simulations performed with the radiative transfer code Aton.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02032v1.title: Albatross: A scalable simulation-based inference pipeline for analysing stellar streams in the Milky Way
