As the first luminous structures, these stars seed the first galaxies and begin the process of reionization. We construct an analytic model to self-consistently trace theformation of Pop III stars inside minihalos.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03258v1.title: Introducing the Texas Euclid Survey for Lyman Alpha (TESLA) Survey: Initial Study Correlating Galaxy Properties to Lyman-Alpha Emission
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03258v1.summary: The Texas Euclid Survey for Lyman-Alpha (TESLA) is a spectroscopic survey in the 10 square degree of the Euclid North Ecliptic Pole (NEP) field. Using TESLA, we study how the physical properties of Ly man-alpha emitters (LAEs) correlate with Lymanalpha emission to understand the escape of LymanAlpha from galaxies at redshifts 2 -- 3.5. We present an analysis of 43 LAEs performed in the NEP field using early data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2205.01015v2.title: The origin of ultramassive white dwarfs: hints from Gaia EDR3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2205.01015v2.summary: Gaia Data Release 2 revealed a population of ultramassive white dwarfs on the                Q branch that are moving anomalously fast for a local disc population with young photometric ages. As the velocity dispersion of stars in the localdisc increases with age, a proposed explanation of these white dwarffs is that they experience a cooling delay.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.07919v2.title: A model for the infrared-radio correlation of main-sequence galaxies at GHz frequencies and its dependence on redshift and stellar mass
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.07919v2.summary: The infrared-radio correlation (IRRC) of star-forming galaxies can be used to estimate their star formation rate (SFR) based on radio luminosity. For application in future deep radiosurveys, it is crucial to know whether the IRRC persists at high redshift z.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01991v2.title: One Relation for All Wavelengths: The Far-Ultraviolet to Mid-Infrared Milky Way Spectroscopic R(V) Dependent Dust Extinction Relationship
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01991v2.summary: Dust extinction is one of the fundamental measurements of dust grain sizes, Compositions, and shapes. Most of the wavelength dependent variations seen in Milky Way extinction are strongly correlated with the single parameter R(V)=A(V)/E(B-V. Existing literature relationships show significant deviations compared to this relationship especially in the far-ultraviolet and mid-infrared. We find tentative evidence that the relationship may not be linear with A(V)/R(V.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.07668v2.title: Constraining axion and compact dark matter with interstellar medium heating
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.07668v2.summary: Cold interstellar gas systems have been used to constrain dark matter (DM) models by the condition that the heating rate from DM must be lower than the cooling rate of the gas. We use the interstellar medium of a gas-rich dwarf galaxy, Leo                T, and a Milky Way-environment gas cloud, G33.4-8.0. Our limits are complementary to DM direct detection metrics.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01378v2.title: A Diverse Population of z ~ 2 ULIRGs Revealed by JWST Imaging
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.01378v2.summary: Four ultra-luminous infrared galaxies (ULIRGs) observed with JWST/NIRcam in the Cosmos Evolution Early Release Science program. The objects were originally selected at 24                $\mu$m and have strong polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon emission features. The four objects have similar stellar masses but otherwise are quite diverse.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03058v1.title: A VLT/VIMOS view of two $Planck$ multiple-cluster systems: structure and galaxy properties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.03058v1.summary: We analysed spectroscopic data obtained with VLT-VIMOS for two multiple-cluster systems. We found that the two systems are populated mainly with passive galaxies. We also find evidence for remaining star formation activity in the highest-redshift cluster of PLCKG$214.6+36.9$.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15886v2.title: Refining the 2022 OJ 287 impact flare arrival epoch
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15886v2.summary: The 2022 impact flare, namely flare number 26, is rather peculiar as it breaks the typical pattern of two impact flares per 12-year cycle. This is the third bremsstrahlung flare of the current cycle that follows the already-observed 2015 and 2019 impact flares from OJ~287.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15008v2.title: Fundamental effective temperature measurements for eclipsing binary stars -- IV. Selection of new benchmark stars and first results for HD 22064
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15008v2.summary: HD22064 is an ideal benchmark star for "end-to-end" tests of the stellar parameters measured by large-scalespectroscopic surveys. The techniques described here for HD22064 can be applied to the other eclipsing binaries in the sample in order to create an all-sky network of such benchmark stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12970v2.title: Abundance ratios of OH/CO and HCO+/CO as probes of the cosmic ray ionization rate in diffuse clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12970v2.summary: The cosmic-ray ionization rate (CRIR) is one of the key parameters controlling the formation and destruction of various molecules in molecularclouds. The current most commonly used CRIR tracers, such as H$_3^+$, are hard to detect and require the presence of background massive stars for absorption measurements. We propose an alternative method to infer the CRIR in diffuse clouds using the abundance of OH/CO and HCO$^+$/CO.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02997v1.title: Right-Handed Neutrino Dark Matter with Forbidden Annihilation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02997v1.summary: The seesaw mechanism with three right-handed neutrinos has one as a well-motivated dark matter candidate if stable. The other two can explain asymmetry via the thermal leptogenesis scenario. We explore the possibility of introducing additional particles to make the right- handed Neutrino dark matter in thermal equilibrium and freeze out through a forbiddenihilation channel.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.07059v2.title: KDG 64: a large dwarf spheroidal or a small ultradiffuse satellite of Messier 81
http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.07059v2.summary: Low-mass early-type galaxies, including dwarf spheroidals (dSph) and brighter dwarf ellipticals (dE), dominate the galaxy population in groups and clusters. KDG 64 is a local analogue of smaller UDGs in the Coma and Virgo clusters and is probably a transitional dSph-UDG object.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02969v1.title: The fastest hot subdwarfs revisited
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02969v1.summary: Hyper-velocity stars (HVS) are enigmatic objects because they are travelling so fast that they escape from the Galaxy. Among hot subdwarfs, only one such star is known, the He-sdO US 708. The Hyper-MUCHFUSS collaboration provided additional HVS candidates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02958v1.title: Spatial metallicity variations of mono-temperature stellar populations revealed by early-type stars in LAMOST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02958v1.summary: We investigate the radial metallicity gradients on the Galactocentric $X$--$Y$ plane. We also identify five potential metal-poor substructures with large metalicity excess dispersions. High-velocity clouds are not well mixed with the pre-existing Galactic disk ISM within 0.3\,Gyr.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08765v3.title: Model-Independent Mass Reconstruction of the Hubble Frontier Field Clusters with MARS Based on Self-Consistent Strong Lensing Data
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08765v3.summary: We present new strong-lensing (SL) mass reconstruction of the six HubbleFrontier Fields (HFF) clusters with the MAximum-entropy ReconStruction (MARS) algorithm. With $100-200$ multiple images per cluster, we construct solutions with small scatters of multiple images in both source and image planes. We find that in general, these mass hypertpeaks are in excellent spatial agreement with the member galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02907v1.title: The new detection of blue straggler stars in 50 open clusters using Gaia DR3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02907v1.summary: The presence of blue straggler stars (BSS) in Galacticopen clusters offers favorable conditions for detailed studies. With the help of Gaia DR3, the number of identified open clusters continuouslyincreases, and the determination of star cluster members is more reliable. We identified 138 BSS that had not been reported before in 50 open clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02857v1.title: A MUSE view of the multiple interacting system HCG 31
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02857v1.summary: We present, for the first time, spatially resolved spectroscopy for the entire Hickson Compact Group 31. We derived radial velocity and dispersion velocitymaps, maps of the ionization mechanism of the system, chemical abundances and their distribution over the whole system. We also reconstructed the star formation history of the four galaxies in the group.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02815v1.title: MOA-2022-BLG-249Lb: Nearby microlensing super-Earth planet detected from high-cadence surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02815v1.summary: The lensing eventMOA-2022-BLG-249 exhibits a brief positive anomaly that lasted for about 1 day. The anomaly is better explained by the planetary model than thebinary-source model. The planet detection demonstrates the elevatedmicrolensing sensitivity of the current high-cadence lensing surveys to low-mass planets.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02803v1.title: Witnessing a Transformation to Blue-cored Dwarf Early-type Galaxies in Filaments and the Cluster Outskirts: Gas-phase Abundances and Internal Kinematics Perspectives
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02803v1.summary: The presence of transitional dwarf galaxies in filaments and clusteroutskirts may be closely related to pre-processing in the filament. The underlying mechanism is not yet comprehensively understood. We present the chemical and kinematical properties of three blue-cored early-type galaxies (dE(bc)s) in the Virgo cluster.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.02876v2.title: Small-scale clumping of dark matter and the mean free path of ionizing photons at $z=6$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.02876v2.summary: The mean free path of ionizing photons in the $z = 6$ intergalacticmedium (IGM) was measured to be very short, presenting a challenge to existing cosmology models. We use two classes of models to contrast against the standard CDM prediction: (1) thermal relic warm matter (WDM), representing models with suppressed small-scale power; (2) ultralight axion exhibiting a white noise-like power enhancement.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.11266v2.title: The Morphology of Reionization in a Dynamically Clumpy Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.11266v2.summary: A recent measurement of the Lyman-limit mean free path at $z = 6$ suggests it may have been very short. We address this question with a dynamical sub-grid model for the sinks based on radiative hydrodynamics simulations. Compared to assuming a fullypressure-smoothed IGM, our dynamical treatment reduces ionized bubble sizes by $10-20%.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02784v1.title: Strong Lensed QSOs with Variability Detectable by LSST: How many are there?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02784v1.summary: Strong lensed quasi-stellar objects (QSOs) are valuable probes of the tumultuous universe. The Vera C. Rubin Telescope Legacy Survey of Space and Time (LSST) uses QSOs for reverberation mapping and time delay measurements. We expect 30--40% of the mock lensed QSO sample, which corresponds to $1,000, to exhibit variability detectable with LSST.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02779v1.title: Hyades Member K2-136c: The Smallest Planet in an Open Cluster with a Precisely Measured Mass
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02779v1.summary: K2-136 is a late-K dwarf in the Hyades open cluster with three known, transiting planets and an age of $650\pm70$ Myr. The planets K1-136b, c, and d have periods of $8.0, $17.3, and $25.6$ days and radii of $1.014, $3.13, and$1.565. Mass estimates may be feasible with more radial velocity observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02684v1.title: Cosmic ray propagation in turbulent magnetic fields
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02684v1.summary: Propagation of cosmic rays (CRs) in turbulent and magnetized astrophysical media is a long-standing problem. This review focuses on selected recent theoretical findings made. In particular, we address the problem of perpendicular and parallelpropagation. We identify the conditions when the perpendicular propagation is superdiffusive and diffusive.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02666v1.title: Early Results from GLASS-JWST XXIII: The transmission of Lyman-alpha from UV-faint z ~ 3-6 galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02666v1.summary: Lyman-alpha (Ly$\alpha$) emission from galaxies can be used to trace neutralHydrogen in the epoch of reionization. There is a degeneracy between the attenuation of Ly$\ alpha$ in the intergalactic medium (IGM) and the line                profile emitted from the galaxy. Large shifts of the systemic redshift of galaxies can boost Ly$ \alpha$ transmission in the interstellar medium.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12291v1.title: Evolution of open clusters with or without black holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12291v1.summary: Binary black holes (BHs) can be formed dynamically in the centers of star clusters. The high natal kicks for stellar-mass BHs used in previous works made it hard to retain them. Recent studies propose kick velocities that are lower due to the fallback of the SN ejecta.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.09097v3.title: Early results from GLASS-JWST. XIV: A spectroscopically confirmed protocluster 650 million years after the Big Bang
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.09097v3.summary: We present the spectroscopic confirmation of a protocluster at $z=7.88$ behind the galaxy cluster Abell2744 (hereafter A2744-z7p9OD) Using JWSTNIRSpec, we find seven galaxies within a projected radius of 60kpc. The galaxies reside in an overdensity around $>20\times$ greater than a randomvolume. They do not show strong Lyman-alpha emission.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.06247v2.title: CLEAR: High-Ionization [Ne V] $λ$3426 Emission-line Galaxies at $1.4 <z< 2.3$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.06247v2.summary: We analyze a sample of 25 [Ne V] emission-line galaxies at $1.4<z<2.3$ using Hubble Space Telescope/Wide Field Camera 3 G102 and G141grism observations from the CANDELS Lyman-$\alpha$ Emission at Reionization(CLEAR) survey. The majority of the galaxies have properties consistent with ionization from active galactic nuclei (AGN)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12197v1.title: The Gaia-ESO Survey: Empirical estimates of stellar ages from lithium equivalent widths (EAGLES)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12197v1.summary: We present an empirical model of age-dependent photospheric lithiumdepletion. The model is used to obtain age estimates and posterior age probability distributions. The method is validated on a sample of exoplanet-hosting young stars. We obtain better than 10 per cent precision in age, and excellent agreement with published ages.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12169v1.title: Constraints on the Galactic Centre environment from \textit{Gaia} hypervelocity stars III: Insights on a possible companion to Sgr A*
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12169v1.summary: We consider a scenario in which Sgr A* is in a massive black hole binary(MBHB) with an as-of-yet undetected supermassive or intermediate-mass blackhole companion. Dynamical encounters between this MBHB and single stars in its immediate vicinity would eject hypervelocity stars (HVSs) with velocities beyond the Galactic escape velocity. We simulate the ejection of HVSs via the `MBHB slingshot' scenario.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12137v1.title: Photometric determination of the mass accretion rates of pre-main-sequence stars. VIII. Recent star formation in NGC 299
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12137v1.summary: We studied the properties of the young stellar populations in the NGC 299 mistakenlycluster in the Small Magellanic Cloud. We found evidence for the existence of two populations of PMS stars, with median ages of 20 Myr and 50 Myr respectively. The average mass accretion rate for these stars is comparable to that found in other low-metallicity, low-density clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2204.02082v2.title: The evolution of the radio luminosity function of group galaxies in COSMOS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2204.02082v2.summary: We present a study of radio luminosity functions (RLFs) of group grotesquegalaxies. The study was based on the Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array-COSMOS 3 GHz Large project. Group galaxies associated with AGN or SFGs dominate the GG RLF at z_med= 0.3. At z ~ 1, the peak in the RLF is mainly driven by AGN, while at z > 1SFGs dominate.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12107v1.title: Using multiobjective optimization to reconstruct interferometric data (I)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12107v1.summary: Multiobjective Evolutionary Algorithm Based onDecomposition, or MOEA/D. Algorithm is faster than any other Bayesian method and explores more solutions than Regularized Maximum Likelihood methods (RML) Algorithm used to recover static images and polarimetric reconstructions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12061v1.title: Nuclear activity in $z<0.3$ QSO 2's mainly triggered by galaxy mergers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12061v1.summary: We investigate the role of the close environment on the nuclear activity of 436 nearby ($z<0.3$) QSO 2's -- selected from SDSS-III spectra. The main difference is an excess of nuclear activity in the QSOs hosts, which is almost twice that of the control galaxies. Our results favour a scenario in which nuclear activity is triggered by close galaxy interactions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.07237v2.title: Physical and chemical complexity in high-mass star-forming regions with ALMA. I. Overview and evolutionary trends of physical properties
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.07237v2.summary: In this study, we investigate how physical properties, such as the density and temperature profiles, evolve on core scales through the evolutionarysequence during high-mass star formation. We observed 11 high- mass star-forming regions with ALMA at 3 mm wavelengths. The temperature structure and radial profiles are determined by modeling molecular emission of CH3CN and CH313CN with XCLASS.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.04542v2.title: Chemical Cartography with LAMOST and Gaia Reveal Azimuthal and Spiral Structure in the Galactic Disk
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.04542v2.summary: We use chemical cartography to explore the metallicity distribution of OBAF-type diskstars from the LAMOST survey and a complementary sample of disk giant stars from Gaia DR3. We use these samples to constrain the radial and verticalmetallicity gradients across the Galactic disk. We also explore whether there are detectable azimuthal variations in the metalicity distribution on top of the radial gradient.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12045v1.title: Rotational spectroscopy of oxirane-\textit{2,2}-$d_2$, $c$-CD$_2$CH$_2$O, and its tentative detection toward IRAS 16293$-$2422~B
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12045v1.summary: We prepared a sample of oxirane doubly deuterated at one C atom and studied its rotational spectrum in the laboratory for the first time between 120~GHz and 1094~GHz. Accurate spectroscopic parameters up to eighth order were determined, and the calculated rest frequencies were used to identify $c$-CD$_2$CH$_ 2$O tentatively in the interstellar medium in the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11158v2.title: A search for transients in the Reionization Lensing Cluster Survey (RELICS): Three new supernovae
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11158v2.summary: The Reionization Cluster Survey (RELICS) imaged 41 galaxy clusters with theHubble Space Telescope. Each cluster was imaged to about 26.5 AB mag in three optical and four near-infrared bands. We find six prominent supernova (SN) candidates over the 41 fields.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12028v1.title: Transition disc nature of post-AGB binary systems confirmed by mid-infrared interferometry
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12028v1.summary: Circumbinary discs around evolved post-asymptotic giant branch (post-AGB) binary systems show many similar properties to protoplanetary discs around young stars. Deficits of near-infrared (near-IR) flux in the spectral energy distributing (SEDs) of such systems hints towards large dust-free cavities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.14460v4.title: Astrometric Microlensing of Primordial Black Holes with Gaia
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.14460v4.summary: The Gaia space telescope allows for unprecedented accuracy for astrometric measurements of stars in the Galaxy. We explore the sensitivity of Gaia to detect primordial black hole (PBH) dark matter through the distortion that PBHs would create in the apparent trajectories of background stars. We present a novel calculation of the lensing probability, and we combine this with the existing Gaia eDR3 stellar catalog.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2201.07494v2.title: Spectral and polarization properties of reflected X-ray emission from black hole accretion discs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2201.07494v2.summary: X-ray polarimetric missions planned for this decade will significantlyenhance our knowledge of compact accreting sources. We present a yet missing piece in the global polarization models of black hole accretion discs. The polarization degree andangle are in agreement with analytical approximations previously appearing in the literature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11980v1.title: A 3D view of dwarf galaxies with Gaia and VLT/FLAMES I. The Sculptor dwarf spheroidal
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11980v1.summary: We present a new homogeneous survey of VLT/FLAMES LR8 line-of-sight radialvelocities (vlos) for 1604 resolved red giant branch stars in Sculptor. In addition, we provide reliable Ca II triplet                metallicities, [Fe/H], for 1339 of these stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11929v1.title: Vorticity and magnetic dynamo from subsonic expansion waves
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11929v1.summary: This work concentrates on the effect of an irrotational forcing on aMagnetized flow in the presence of rotation, baroclinicity, shear, or a combination of them. By including magnetic field in the model we can evaluate the occurrence of dynamo on both small and large scales.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11911v1.title: Confirmation of the standard cosmological model from red massive galaxies $\sim600$ Myr after the Big Bang
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11911v1.summary: Lebb\'e et al. used multi-band infrared images captured by the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) to discover a population of red massive galaxies that formed approximately 600 million years after the BigBang. The authors reported an extraordinarily large density of these galaxies, with stellar masses exceeding $10 trillion solar masses.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11895v1.title: The Performance of FAST with Ultra-Wide Bandwidth Receiver at 500-3300 MHz
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11895v1.summary: A new Ultra-Wide Bandwidth (UWB) receiver has been mounted in the FAST feed cabin. The whole UWB band is separated into four independent bands. Each band has 1048576 channels in total, resulted in a spectral resolution of 1 kHz. At 500-3300 MHz, the antenna gain is around 14.3-7.7 K/Jy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11831v1.title: Radio Polarization: A Powerful Resource for Understanding the Blazar Divide
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11831v1.summary: With high-sensitivity kiloparsec-scale radio polarimetry, we can examine the jet-medium interactions and get a better understanding of the blazar divide in Radio-loud (RL) AGN. The Fanaroff-Riley (FR) dichotomy can also be studied assuming RL unification and looking through the lens of blazars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.08010v3.title: Mock X-ray observations of hot gas with L-Galaxies semi-analytic models of galaxy formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.08010v3.summary: We create mock X-ray observations of hot gas in galaxy clusters with a new extension of L-Galaxies semi-analytic model of galaxy formation. Based on the model outputs, we build some mock light cones, then generate mock spectra with SOXS package. Using the mock data, we simulate the mock x-ray spectra for ROSAT all-sky survey. Then, we consider the design parameters of HUBS and simulate the observation of the halo hot gas.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11784v1.title: MeerKAT discovery of a double radio relic and odd radio circle
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11784v1.summary: A large double radio relic is associated with the merging galaxy cluster PSZ2 G277.93+12.34 and a new oddradio circle, ORC J1027-4422, both found in deep MeerKAT 1.3 GHz wide-band data. The angular separation of the two arc-shaped cluster relics is 16 arcmin                or 2.6 Mpc for a cluster redshift of z = 0.158. The discovery of a new single radio circle makes it the 4th known single ORC.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11774v1.title: Exponential galaxy discs as the quasi-stationary distribution in a Markov chain model simulating stellar scattering
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11774v1.summary: Previous models have shown that stochastic scattering of stars in a two-dimensional galaxy disc can generate a time-independent surface density. Here we show that similar profiles result from an outward scattering bias. The trend towards a near-exponential surface profile is robust, even if the scattering intensity has moderate radial and time dependences.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11715v1.title: MaNGA DynPop -- IV. Stacked total density profile of galaxy groups and clusters from combining dynamical models of integral-field stellar kinematics and galaxy-galaxy lensing
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11715v1.summary: We present the measurement of total and stellar/dark matter decomposed mass around a sample of galaxy groups and clusters with dynamicalmasses derived from integral-field stellar kinematics from the MaNGA survey. We find that a good fit to both data sets requires a stellar mass normalization about 3 times higher than that derived from the NASA-Sloan Atlas catalog.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11714v1.title: MaNGA DynPop -- III. Accurate stellar dynamics vs. stellar population relations in 6000 early-type and spiral galaxies: fundamental plane, mass-to-light ratios, total density slopes, and dark matter fractions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11714v1.summary: We show that the inclination-corrected mass plane (MP) for both early-type.galaxies (ETGs) and late-type galaxies (LTGs) links dynamical mass and stellar population. We find a clear parabolic relation between. the total mass-to-light ratio within a sphere of radius $R_{\rm e}$, and. $lg(M/L)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11712v1.title: MaNGA DynPop -- II. Global stellar population, gradients, and star-formation histories from integral-field spectroscopy of 10K galaxies: link with galaxy rotation, shape, and total-density gradients
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11712v1.summary: We analyze the global stellar population, radial gradients and non-parametric star formation history of 10,000 galaxies from the MaNGA Survey. We find that younger galaxies are more metal-poor at fixed distances. Galaxies with high stellar mass have the highest star-formation rate at earlier times.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11711v1.title: MaNGA DynPop -- I. Quality-assessed stellar dynamical modelling from integral-field spectroscopy of 10K nearby galaxies: a catalogue of masses, mass-to-light ratios, density profiles and dark matter
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11711v1.summary: This is the first paper in our series on the combined analysis of the metrics and stellar Population (DynPop) for the MaNGA survey in the final SDSSData Release 17 (DR17) Here we present a catalogue of dynamically-determined quantities for over 10000 nearby galaxies. The dynamical properties are extracted using the axisymmetric Jeans Anisotropic Modelling method.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06733v2.title: Probing the Origin of Changing-look Quasar Transitions with Chandra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06733v2.summary: Extremely variable quasars can also show strong changes in broad line emissions. They are known as Changing Look Quasars (CLQs) We present a pilot sample of CLQs with X-ray Observations both in the bright and faint states. It is highly likely that the observed changes are due to the changing accretion rate of the supermassive black hole.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11581v1.title: Anatomy of galactic star formation history: Roles of different modes of gas accretion, feedback, and recycling
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11581v1.summary: We investigate how the diverse star formation histories observed acrossgalaxy masses emerged using models that evolve under gas accretion from hosthalos. They also include ejection of interstellar matter by supernova feedback,recycling of ejected matter and preventive feedback that partially hinders gasAccretion. The fiducial schemereproduces dramatic diminishment in star formation rate (SFR) after its peak.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11541v1.title: Massive black holes in galactic nuclei: Theory and Simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11541v1.summary: Massive black holes are fundamental constituents of our cosmos. Understanding their formation from cosmic dawn, their growth,and the emergence of the first, rare quasars in the early Universe remains one of our greatest challenges. Multi-messenger astrophysics brings exciting prospects for tracing the origin, growth and merger history of massive black holes across cosmic ages.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00508v2.title: Surrogate forward models for population inference on compact binary mergers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00508v2.summary: Merger observations can constrain the uncertain parameters that describe the underlying processes in the evolution of stars and binary systems. We demonstrate that binary blackhole populations can be used to measure cosmological parameters describing the redshift-dependent star formation rate and metallicity distribution. We present a method that uses artificial neural networks to emulate binary population synthesis computer models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.09259v2.title: Quasi-spiral solution to the mixed intracluster medium and the universal entropy profile of galaxy clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.09259v2.summary: Well-resolved galaxy clusters often show a large-scale quasi-spiral structure. We show that a spiral structure provides a natural quasi-stationary solution for the mixed intracluster medium. The solutionpersists in the presence of uniform or differential rotation, and can accommodate both an inflow and an outflow.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07501v3.title: High-Mass Starless Clumps: Dynamical State and Correlation Between Physical Parameters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07501v3.summary: We have previously built a sample of 463 high-mass starless clumps (HMSCs) across theinner Galactic plane covered by multiple continuum surveys. Here, we use CO(2-1) line data from the SEDIGISM survey to investigate the global dynamical state of HMSCs. We find that most HMSCs are highly turbulent with a median Mach number 8.2, and 55% of them are gravitationally bound.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11296v1.title: Hydrodynamic Evolution of Sgr A East: The Imprint of A Supernova Remnant in the Galactic Center
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11296v1.summary: We perform three-dimensional numerical simulations to study the hydrodynamic evolving of Sgr A East. We address the Implications of these results for our understanding of the Galactic center environment. All three simulations can roughly reproduce the extent of S gr A East and the position andmorphology of an arc-shaped thermal X-ray feature, known as the "ridge"

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11269v1.title: High-velocity CP2 stars in the Galactic halo
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11269v1.summary: A small fraction of chemically peculiar stars, the CP2 stars, were recently found to be located far from the Galactic plane. These objects are thought to belong to the Galactic halo, which is unexpected for this class of objects. The orbits of these stars are in agreement with an emphatically origin in the Galactic disk where they were probably ejected through dynamicalinteractions or in the binary supernova scenario.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11264v1.title: Revisiting the black hole mass of M87* using VLT/MUSE Adaptive Optics Integral Field Unit data I: Ionized gas kinematics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11264v1.summary: The stellar-based black hole mass measurement of M87 is twice that determines via ionized gas kinematics. We use both.Narrow and Wide Field Mode integral field spectroscopic data from the Multi.Unit Spectroscopic Explorer instrument to model the k.inematics of multiple nuclear gas emission lines. The dataset reveals complexities in the nuclear.iablyionized gasKinematics not seen in earlier observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00661v2.title: Spherical Harmonic Representation of Energetic Neutral Atom Flux Components Observed by IBEX
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00661v2.summary: The Interstellar Boundary Explorer (IBEX) images the heliosphere by observingenergetic neutral atoms (ENAs) The IBEX-Hi instrument onboard IBEX provides full-sky maps of ENA fluxes. A narrow and bright emission from a circular region in the sky, dubbed the IBEX ribbon, is visible.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11240v1.title: The GeMS/GSAOI Galactic Globular Cluster Survey (G4CS) II: Characterization of 47 Tuc with Bayesian Statistics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11240v1.summary: We present a photometric analysis of globular cluster 47 Tuc (NGC\,104) using near-IR imaging data from the GeMS/GSAOI Galactic Globular Cluster Survey. Our best estimate for the age of 47 Tuc is 12.42 Gyr, and our true distance modulus estimate is 13.250 Gyr.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11230v1.title: Application of the emission model to PAHs and C$_{60}$ II.Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbon emission model in photodissociation regions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11230v1.summary: We present a charge distribution-based emission model that calculates theinfrared spectrum of fullerenes. We further used our model tosimulate emission from polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) and C$_{60}$ at five positions in the cavity of reflection nebula NGC~7023.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11210v1.title: Investigating the $M_{GCS}-M_h$ Relation in the Most Massive Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11210v1.summary: The relation between the total mass contained in the globular clusters of a galaxy and the mass of its dark matter halo has been found observationally to nearly linear over five decades of mass. However, the high-mass end of thisrelation is not well determined from previous data and shows large scatter. We analyze globular cluster systems of a homogeneous sample of 11 brightest cluster galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11194v1.title: Digging deeper into NGC\,6868 I: stellar population
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11194v1.summary: We used Gemini integral field unit observations to map the stellar population of NGC 686868. This galaxy is dominated by old metal-rich populations with a negative metallicity gradient. No signs of ordered stellar motion are found and the stellar kinematics is dispersion dominated. Mg$_2$ shows a shallow gradient, compatible with the occurrence of mergers in the past.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11192v1.title: The reionising bubble size distribution around galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11192v1.summary: Constraining when and how reionisation began is pivotal for understanding when the first galaxies formed. Lyman-alpha (Ly$\alpha$) emission from galaxies is currently our most promising probe of these early stages. At z>7 themajority of galaxies detected with Ly$\ alpha$ are in candidate overdensities. The brightest galaxies have bubble size distributions with highest characteristic size and least scatter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11190v1.title: Kinematics of Galactic Centre clouds shaped by shear-seeded solenoidal turbulence
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11190v1.summary: Central Molecular Zone (CMZ) is a kinematically unusual environment. It has high velocity dispersions and a steepened size-linewidth relation. It also has a significantly lower star formation rate than expected by its large amount of dense gas. An important factor in explaining the low SFR is the turbulence driving mechanism.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11188v1.title: Key Science Goals for the Next-Generation Event Horizon Telescope
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11188v1.summary: The Event Horizon Telescope (EHT) has led to the first images of a supermassive black hole. Proposed upgrades to this array would sharply improve the resolution, dynamic range, and temporal coverage of the existing EHT. These improvements will uniquely enable a wealth of new discoveries related to black hole science.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11187v1.title: Intranight Optical Variability of Blazars and Radio-quiet Quasars using the ZTF Survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11187v1.summary: We explore the potential of the ongoing Zwicky-Transient-Facility (ZTF) survey for studying Intra-Night Optical Variability (INOV) of active galacticnuclei (AGN) We build a well-defined sample of 53 blazars and another sample of 132 radio-quiet quasars matched to the blazar sample in the redshift-magnitude plane. Median durations for both sets of sessions are 3.7 hours.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11181v1.title: Spectroscopy from Photometry: A Population of Extreme Emission Line Galaxies at $1.7 \lesssim z \lesssim 6.7$ Selected with JWST Medium Band Filters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11181v1.summary: We use JWST/NIRCam medium band photometry in a single pointing of the NIRISS Unbiased Cluster Survey (CANUCS) to identify 118 Extreme Mission Line Galaxies (EELGs) over $1.7. We show that our medium band color selections are able to select galaxies based on emission line equivalent width (EW), which is advantageous to more commonly used selections.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11179v1.title: The Northern Cross Fast Radio Burst project -- III. The FRB-magnetar connection in a sample of nearby galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11179v1.summary: Fast radio bursts (FRBs) are millisecond-radio transients observed at incomprehensible distances. The nature of their progenitors is still under debate, although magnetars are invoked by most models. We carried out an FRB search in a sample of seven nearby galaxies with the Northern Cross radio telescope for a total of 692 h.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11177v1.title: An analytic surface density profile for $Λ$CDM halos and gravitational lensing studies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11177v1.summary: We introduce an analytic surface density profile for dark matter halos that reproduces the structure of simulated halos of mass. The two-parameter function has an analytic                deflection potential and is more accurate than the projected Navarro, Frenk &White (NFW) profile commonly adopted at this mass scale.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11178v1.title: Dust attenuation law in JWST galaxies at z = 7-8
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11178v1.summary: Attenuation curves in galaxies depend on dust chemical composition, content, and grain size distribution. Such parameters are related to intrinsic galaxyproperties such as metallicity, star formation rate, and stellar age. One out of three galaxies shows a characteristic MW bump, typically associated to the presence of smallcarbonaceous dust grains such as PAHs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10972v1.title: Multi-epoch hard X-ray view of Compton-thick AGN Circinus Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10972v1.summary: The circumnuclear material around Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) is one of theessential components of the obscuration-based unification model. In this paper, we present the multi-epoch broadband X-ray spectral modelling of a nearby nearby Compton-thick AGN in Circinus galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.18123v2.title: Globular Clusters in the Galactic Center Region: expected behavior in the infalling and merger scenario
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.18123v2.summary: The infall and merger scenario of massive clusters in the Milky Way's potential well is reexamined to understand how the stars of the merging clusters are redistributed during andafter the merger process. We used simulations with a highresolution concentrated in the 300 pc around the Galactic center. We detect that the least massive clusters are quickly destroyed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2205.15325v2.title: FIREbox: Simulating galaxies at high dynamic range in a cosmological volume
http://arxiv.org/abs/2205.15325v2.summary: FIREbox offers a baseline prediction of galaxy formation theory in aCDM Universe. At low z, FIREbox predicts a peak in the stellar-mass--halo-mass relation, but also a higher abundance of massive galaxies and a higher cosmic star formation rate density than observed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10471v2.title: WISDOM Project -- XV. Giant Molecular Clouds in the Central Region of the Barred Spiral Galaxy NGC 5806
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10471v2.summary: We identify $170$ spatially- and spectrally-resolved giant                molecular clouds (GMCs) These clouds have comparable sizes and larger gas masses than those of clouds in the Milky Way disc. High velocity dispersions are observed in the nuclear ring of NGC 5806.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10886v1.title: VLBI Astrometry of Radio Stars to Link Radio and Optical Celestial Reference Frames. I. HD 199178 $\&$ AR Lacertae
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10886v1.summary: HD 199178 and ARLacertae as the target for a pilot program for the frame link. The measured parallax of HD 199178 is $8.949 mas and the proper motion is $23.459 mas. With the updated astrometric parameters for these two stars, there is a 25% reduction of the uncertainties on the Y axis for both orientation and spin parameters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10863v1.title: Properties of the dense cores and filamentary structures in the Vela C molecular cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10863v1.summary: Cores and filamentary structures make up 40% of the total mass of Vela C. Most of the material is in the low-density molecular background cloud. We selected 68 filaments with at least one side that appeared not aligned with adjacent structures. A large fraction of the filaments may definitely be considered supercritical.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10772v1.title: Photometric metallicity for 694233 Galactic giant stars from Gaia DR3 synthetic Stromgren photometry. Metallicity distribution functions of halo sub-structures
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10772v1.summary: We use the calibrations by Calamida et. al. and by Hilker et al. to obtain photometric metallicities for a selected sample of 694233 old Galactic giant stars. The zero point of both sets of photometric.metallicities has been shifted to to ensure optimal match with the spectroscopic [Fe/H] values for 44785 stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09763v2.title: The most massive Population III stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09763v2.summary: Metal-poor, gaseous Population III (Pop III) stars are likely in the range 10-1000 solar masses. Such extreme Pop III stars were sufficiently numerous to be the seeds of supermassive black holes at high redshifts. We conclude that the extreme-value formalism provides an effective way to constrain the stellar initial mass function.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.03158v2.title: EMPRESS. XI. SDSS and JWST Search for Local and z~4-5 Extremely Metal-Poor Galaxies (EMPGs): Clustering and Chemical Properties of Local EMPGs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.03158v2.summary: We search for local extremely metal-poor galaxies (EMPGs) by broadband color excess and machine-learning techniques. We find galaxy candidates with emission weaker than the local EMPGs and known high-$z$ galaxies. Some of these candidates may potentially break the lowest metallicity limit known to date. We also compare mass-metallicity relations (MZRs) of the EMPG's and those of galaxies at $z\sim$ 0--4 with a steady chemical evolution model.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10690v1.title: What Does the Milky Way Look Like?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10690v1.summary: The overall spiral structure morphology of the MilkyWay remains somewhat uncertain. In the last two decades, accurate distance measurements have provided us with an opportunity to solve this issue. We propose that our galaxy has a multiple-arm morphology that consists of two-arm symmetry in the inner parts and that extends to the outer parts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10654v1.title: The APO-K2 Catalog. I. 7,673 Red Giants with Fundamental Stellar Parameters from APOGEE DR17 Spectroscopy and K2-GAP Asteroseismology
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10654v1.summary: We present a catalog of fundamental stellar properties for 7,673 evolvedstars, including stellar radii and masses. The APO-K2 sample has a large population of low metallicity stars. We argue that this may reflect offsets in the adopted fundamental temperature scale for metal-poor stars rather than meetingallicity-dependent issues.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.15705v2.title: Formation of star clusters and enrichment by massive stars in simulations of low-metallicity galaxies with a fully sampled initial stellar mass function
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.15705v2.summary: We present new GRIFFIN project hydrodynamical simulations that model theformation of galactic star cluster populations in low-metallicity ($Z=0.00021$) galaxies. In the simulations, stars are sampled from thestellar initial mass function down to the hydrogen burning limit of $0.08$ M$_\odot. Mass conservation is enforced within a radius of $1$ pc for the formation of massive stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.07270v2.title: The distance to the Serpens South Cluster from H2O masers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.07270v2.summary: CarMA-6 is located at the center of the Serpens South young cluster. From the astrometric fits to maser spots, we derive a distance of 440.7+/-3.5 pc for the protostar. This represents the best direct distance determination obtained so far for an object this young and embedded in this highly obscured region.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10569v1.title: Stellar Collisions in the Galactic Center: Massive Stars, Collision Remnants, and Missing Red Giants
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10569v1.summary: The Milky Way harbors a supermassive black hole (SMBH) at its center, surrounded by a nuclear star cluster. In this dense star cluster, directly collisions can occur between stars before they evolve off the main-sequence. Collisions between lower mass stars can produce massive stars, and there may be 100 of them in the Galactic Center.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10568v1.title: The Magnetohydrodynamic-Particle-In-Cell Module in Athena++: Implementation and Code Tests
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10568v1.summary: The code is optimized toward efficient vectorization in interpolation and particle deposits. The code is also compatible with static/adaptive mesh refinement, with dynamic load balancing to furtherenhance multi-scale simulations. We anticipate the code to open up the avenue for a wide range of astrophysical and plasma physics applications.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10567v1.title: Optical Emission Model for Binary Black Hole Merger Remnants Travelling through Discs of Active Galactic Nucleus
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10567v1.summary: Active galactic nuclei (AGNs) have been proposed as plausible sites hosting aizablesizable fraction of the binary black hole (BBH) mergers measured through gravitational waves. We present a new predicted radiation signature driven by the passage of a kicked BBH remnant throughout a thin AGNDisc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10563v1.title: X-ray radiative transfer in full 3D with SKIRT
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10563v1.summary: The X-ray band forms an interesting window to study circumnuclear media in great detail. We extended the SKIRT code with Compton scattering on free electrons, photo-absorption and fluorescence by cold atomic gas, and extinction by dust. This includes a novel treatment of extreme-forward scattering by dust, and a detailed description of anomalous Rayleigh scattering.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10538v1.title: Compact Steep Spectrum Radio Sources with Enhanced Star Formation are Smaller than $10\,$kpc
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10538v1.summary: Compact Steep Spectrum (CSS) radio sources are active galactic nuclei that have radio jets propagating only on galactic scales. CSS sources are generallyhosted by massive early-type galaxies with little on-going star formation, but a small fraction are known to have enhanced star formation. The excess starforming in these sources occurred in multiple bursts and ceased prior to theAGN jet being triggered.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11078v1.title: The Evolution of Population III and Extremely Metal-Poor Binary Stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11078v1.summary: Numerical simulations have shown that Population III (Pop III) stars can form in binaries and small clusters. These stars can be in close proximity to each other. If so, they could be subject to binary interactions such as mass exchange. This could profoundly alter their evolution, ionizing UV photons and explosion yields.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10485v1.title: Accurate mass-radius ratios for Hyades white dwarfs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10485v1.summary: We use the ESPRESSO spectrograph at the Very Large Telescope to measure velocity shifts and gravitational redshifts of eight bona fide Hyades white dwarf stars. One star, EGGR\,29, consistently stands out in all diagrams, indicating that it is possibly the remnant of a blue straggler.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02450v2.title: A Tale of 3 Dwarfs: No Extreme Cluster Formation in Extreme Star-Forming Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02450v2.summary: The three blue compact dwarf galaxies ESO185-IG13, ESO338-IG04, and Haro11 have some of the highest known SigmaSFR and published Gamma values. We present new estimates of Gamma for these BCDs in three age intervals (1-10 Myr, 10-100 Myr, 100-400 Myr) We find no evidence that Gamma increases with SigmaS FR.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00782v2.title: Discovery of Extended Fe Ka Complex X-ray Emission in NGC 5728
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00782v2.summary: We find spectrally and spatially-resolved features in the Fe K$\alpha$ complex of the Compton thick (CT) Seyfert NGC 5728. The [red, blue] features have [6.5$\sigma$, 5.3$\'sigma$] significance.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10437v1.title: A Mixture of LBG Overdensities in the Fields of Three $6 < z < 7$ Quasars: Implications for the Robustness of Photometric Selection
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10437v1.summary: The most luminous quasars at $z > 6$ are suspected to be both highly clustered and reside in the most massive dark matter halos. We search for Lyman-break dropout-selected galaxies using HST. We show that we can robustlyselect LBGs consistent with being physically associated with the quasar.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.10259v2.title: A needle in a haystack? Catching Pop III stars in the Epoch of Reionization: I. Pop III star forming environments
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.10259v2.summary: Theoretical studies have suggested that late Pop III star formation is still possible in pristine clouds of high-mass galaxies. Pop III stars are found both in theoutskirts of metal-enriched regions and in isolated, pristine clouds. Regardless of their mass, Pop III hosting galaxies are mostly found on the main sequence, at high star formation rates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10419v1.title: Fading AGN in Post-Starburst Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10419v1.summary: Evidence from the Mapping Nearby Galaxies at APO (MaNGA) survey for fading AGN activity in 6/93 post-starburst galaxies. 5/6 of the galaxies have current AGN which have faded from the peak luminosity required to have ionized the EELRs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.06666v3.title: Early Results from GLASS-JWST. XIX: A High Density of Bright Galaxies at $z\approx10$ in the Abell 2744 Region
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.06666v3.summary: We report the detection of a high density of redshift $z\approx 10$ galaxies behind the foreground cluster Abell 2744. We detect seven bright $z \approx $10$ galaxies with demagnified rest-frame $-22. The GLASS-JWST field contains 5 out of 7 galaxies, distributed along an apparent filamentary structure of 2 Mpc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10403v1.title: Anisotropic Satellite Galaxy Quenching: A Unique Signature of Energetic Feedback by Supermassive Black Holes?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10403v1.summary: Anisotropic galaxy quenching (ASGQ) has been found in observational data and cosmological simulations. The quenched fraction of satellite galaxies is aligned with the orientation of the halo's central galaxy. On average, satellites form stars at a lower rate along the major axis of the central. galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10377v1.title: Constraining the Molecular Gas Content of Fast Radio Burst (FRB) Host Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10377v1.summary: We used Bands 6 and 7 of the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) in Cycles 7 and 8 to search for emission from five fast radio burst (FRB) host galaxies. We detected three of the five galaxies with luminosities $L'(3-2)$ and set upper limits for the other two. As a population, FRB host galaxies track the main locus of star-forming galaxies in the present-day universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10301v1.title: No evidence for p- or d-wave dark matter annihilation from local large-scale structure
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10301v1.summary: If dark matter annihilates into standard model particles with a cross-section which is velocity dependent, then Local Group dwarf galaxies will not be the best place to search for the resulting gamma ray emission. A greater flux would be produced by more distant and massive halos. We find no evidence for either type of annihilation from dark matter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10233v1.title: Massive black holes in galactic nuclei: Observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10233v1.summary: A black hole does not emit light from its interior, nor does it have a surface on which light from nearby sources can be reflected. A massive black hole leaves a dynamical imprint on stars and gas close by. Gas in the immediate vicinity of an accretingmassive black hole can shine so brightly that it outshines the light of the billions of stars in its host galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10173v1.title: A large bubble around the AGB star R Dor detected in the UV
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10173v1.summary: Many asymptotic giant branch (AGB) and supergiant stars exhibit extended797detached shells in the far-infrared, resembling rings or arcs. This paper describes a search of UV extended shells around AGB stars using archival GALEX far-UV images. We identified the fourth discovery of a UV bubble around the AGB star R Dor. All UV bubbles known to date are limited to be within a distance < 350 pc and at high Galactic latitudes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10150v1.title: Dust attenuation in galaxies at cosmic dawn from the FirstLight simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10150v1.summary: We study the behaviour of dust in galaxies at cosmic dawn, z=6-8, by coupling simulations with the radiative transfer code POLARIS. The complex nature of these galaxies and their complex distribution of dust lead to a large diversity of attenuation curves. These follow the Calzetti model only for relatively massive galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10138v1.title: The statistical analysis of the dynamical evolution of the open clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10138v1.summary: We present the dynamical evolution of ten open clusters which were part of previous studies. The study is based on ground-based UBVRI data supplemented by the astrometric data from the Gaiaarchive. The mass segregation in these clusters was quantified by mass grotesquesegregation ratios calculated from the mean edge length.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10125v1.title: The Detection of a Compact Radio Feature in a Seyfert Galaxy After an Accretion Rate Change
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10125v1.summary: The Seyfert 1 galaxy, KUG 1141+371 has been showing a steadily increasing X-ray flux since 2007. It was hypothesised to undergo a rapidboost of mass accretion. Its high brightness temperature indicates the radio emission originates from an AGN.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10081v1.title: Galaxy Morphology Classification Using Multi-Scale Convolution Capsule Network
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.10081v1.summary: The classification of galaxy morphology is a hot issue in astronomicalresearch. We present a multi-scale convolutional capsule network (MSCCN) model. The model achieves 97% accuracy, 96% precision, 98% recall, and 97% F1-score under macroscopic averaging.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.04709v5.title: EMPRESS. IX. Extremely Metal-Poor Galaxies are Very Gas-Rich Dispersion-Dominated Systems: Will JWST Witness Gaseous Turbulent High-z Primordial Galaxies?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.04709v5.summary: We present kinematics of 6 local extremely metal-poor galaxies (EMPGs) with low stellar masses. All the EMPGs show rotational velocities of 5--23 km s$^{-1}$ smaller than the velocity dispersions. This suggests they are dispersion-dominated systems affected by inflow and/or outflow.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09968v1.title: 3D spectroscopy with GTC-MEGARA of the triple AGN candidate in SDSS J102700.40+174900.8
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09968v1.summary: Triple AGN systems are expected to be the result of the hierarchical model of galaxy formation. Since there are very few of them confirmed as such, we present the results of a new study of the triple-AGN candidate SDSSJ102700.40+174900.8 (center nucleus)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09967v1.title: The evolution of radial gradients of MaNGA quiescent elliptical galaxies: inside-out quenching or outer mass growth?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09967v1.summary: Using spatially-resolved fossil record analysis, we reconstruct the archaeological evolution of galaxies. We find that these trends are mainly driven by strong inside-out quenching, without significant outer growth or structural changes overall. Our results suggest a scenario where the main progenitors of local CLE galaxies evolved quasi-passively after an early dissipative phase.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09964v1.title: Gemini Near Infrared Spectrograph -- Distant Quasar Survey: Augmented Spectroscopic Catalog and a Prescription for Correcting UV-Based Quasar Redshifts
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09964v1.summary: Quasars at $z~{\gtrsim}~1$ most often have redshifts measured from rest-frame ultraviolet emission lines. One of the most common such lines, C IV, shows blueshifts up to $5,000. This blueshifting results in highly uncertain redshift determinations. We present measurements for 260 sources from the Gemini Near InfraredSpectrograph.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09942v1.title: NGTS clusters survey IV. Search for Dipper stars in the Orion Nebular Cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09942v1.summary: The dipper is a novel class of young stellar object associated with large flux drops lasting for hours to days. Dippers have been previously studied in young star forming regions including the Orion Complex. Using Next Generation Transit Survey data, we identified variable stars from their lightcurves. We also investigated the occurrence rate of disks in our targets.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09905v1.title: VarIabiLity seLection of AstrophysIcal sources iN PTF (VILLAIN) II. Supervised classification of variable sources
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09905v1.summary: We use supervised learning in the form of a histogram-based gradientboosting classifier to predict spectroscopic SDSS classes using photometry. We achieve highly accurate predictions for 71 million sources with lightcurves in PTF. The full model correctly identifies 92.49 % ofspectroscopically confirmed quasars with a purity of 95.64 %. For similarSupervised models, we recommend using at least 100,000 labeled objects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09904v1.title: Identification and Characterization of a Large Sample of Distant Active Dwarf Galaxies in XMM-SERVS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09904v1.summary: Active dwarf galaxies are important because they contribute to the evolution of dwarf galaxies and can reveal their hosted massive black holes. The sample size of such sources beyond the local universe is still highly limited. We identify 73 active dwarf galaxies at $z<1$, which is the currently largest X-ray-selected sample.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09903v1.title: VarIabiLity seLection of AstrophysIcal sources iN PTF (VILLAIN) I. Structure function fits to 71 million objects
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09903v1.summary: We aim to determine variability parameters for objects in the PalomarTransient Factory (PTF) and explore differences between quasars (QSOs), stars and galaxies. We will relate variability and colour information in preparation for future surveys. With variability and colours, we achieve a photometric selection purity of 99.3% for QSOs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09901v1.title: The Chemodynamics of the Stellar Populations in M31 from APOGEE Integrated Light Spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09901v1.summary: We present analysis of nearly 1,000 near-infrared, integrated light spectra from APOGEE in the inner $\sim$7 kpc of M31. We find a non-axisymmetric velocity field in M31 resulting from the presence of a metal-poor bulge. The chemodynamics of stellar populations encodes information about a galaxy's chemical enrichment and star formation history.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09898v1.title: Accurate Oxygen Abundance of Interstellar Gas in Mrk 71 from Optical and Infrared Spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09898v1.summary: Metallicity of the Universe is a record of thetotal star formation history. Gas-phase metallicity in galaxies is of particular interest as a tracer of accretion andflow processes. metallicities from the widely-used electron.temperature ($T_e$) method are typically 2x lower than the values based on the.recombination line method.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09897v1.title: Better Together: The Complex Interplay Between Radiative Cooling and Magnetic Draping
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09897v1.summary: Magnetic fields accelerate cloud entrainment through magnetic draping. These fields can cause faster cloud destruction in cases of strongly magnetized winds. Magnetic fields also reduce the average overdensity by providing non-thermal pressure. This substantially reduces the acceleration time of cold gas, enhancing cloud survival.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09894v1.title: A SPectroscopic survey of biased halos In the Reionization Era (ASPIRE): JWST Reveals a Filamentary Structure around a z=6.61 Quasar
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09894v1.summary: We present the first results from the JWST ASPIRE program. This program represents an                imaging and spectroscopic survey of 25 reionization-era quasars and their environments. We report the discovery of a filamentary structure traced by the luminous quasar J0305-3150.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09888v1.title: A SPectroscopic survey of biased halos In the Reionization Era (ASPIRE): A First Look at the Rest-frame Optical Spectra of $z > 6.5$ Quasars Using JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09888v1.summary: Eight quasars at $z>6.5 were studied using the JWST/NIRCam Wide Field Slitless Spectroscopy. The new measurements confirm theexistence of billion solar-mass BHs in the reionization epoch. The entire ASPIRE program will eventually cover 25 quasar and provide a statistical sample.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09878v1.title: Simulating Atomic Dark Matter in Milky Way Analogues
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09878v1.summary: Dark sector theories naturally lead to multi- component scenarios for dark matter. In these scenarios, a sub- component can dissipate energy through self-interactions, allowing it to efficiently cool inside galaxies. We show that ADM gas with roughly Standard-Model-like masses can cool to form a rotating "dark disk"

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09879v1.title: The Nature of the Motions of Multiphase Filaments in the Centers of Galaxy Clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09879v1.summary: The intracluster medium (ICM) in the centers of galaxy clusters is heavily influenced by the feedback from supermassive black holes (SMBHs) We developed a new method to measure turbulence in the ICM using multiphase filaments as tracers. The level of turbulent heating computed at small scales is typically an order of magnitude lower than that estimated at the drivingscale.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03042v1.title: JWST NIRSpec spectroscopy of the triply-lensed $z = 10.17$ galaxy MACS0647$-$JD
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.03042v1.summary: We present JWST/NIRSpec prism spectroscopy of MACS0647-JD. The triply-lensed candidate was discovered in HST imaging. It is split into two components A and B. The smaller component B ($r 20$) pc is likely older($\sim$100 Myr) with more dust.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02983v1.title: M92 (NGC~6341) Is a Metal-Complex Globular Cluster with an Atypical Primordial Population
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02983v1.summary: We present a multiple stellar population study of the metal-poor globular                cluster (GC) M92 (NGC 6341) using our own photometric system. We find two groups with slightly different mean metallicities. The MP constitutes about 23\% of the total mass with a more central concentration.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02959v1.title: Evidence for Large Scale, Rapid Gas Inflows in z~2 Star Forming Disks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02959v1.summary: We report high quality H${\alpha}$/CO, imaging spectroscopy of nine massive galaxies on the star forming, Main Sequence (henceforth 'SFGs') near the peak of cosmic galaxy evolution. We find that all nine galaxies exhibit significant non-tangential flows. If this interpretation is correct, our observations imply that gas istransported into the central regions on ~10 dynamical time scales.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14696v2.title: An analysis of the turbulence in the central region of M 42 (Orion Nebula) II: homogeneity and power-spectrum analyses
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14696v2.summary: In this second communication we continue our analysis of the turbulence in the Huygens Region of the Orion Nebula. We find that the higher-ordertransverse structure functions are almost proportional to the second-order transverse structure function. This implies that there is some type of invariant statistical structure in the velocity field. We also obtain and analyse the power-spectrum of the turbulent field.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02910v1.title: Dynamical hotness, star formation quenching and growth of supermassive black holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02910v1.summary: A stellar system is dynamically hot when its kinetic energy is dominated by random motion. We use MaNGA data to obtain inner and outer dispersion of a galaxy. We discuss how secular processes and strong interactions can make a system dynamically hot, and lead to the SMBH growth and star formationquenching.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07398v2.title: Will ALMA Reveal the True Core Mass Function of Protoclusters?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07398v2.summary: Characterizing prestellar cores in star-forming regions is an important step toward the validation of theoretical models of star formation. ALMA observations can potentially provide samples of massive starforming regions up to distances of a few kpc. However, the extraction of real cores from observations is affected by complex projection effects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02829v1.title: Tracing Pop III supernovae with extreme energies through the Sculptor dwarf spheroidal galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02829v1.summary: The Sculptor dwarf spheroidal galaxy is old and metal-poor, making it ideal to study the earliest chemical enrichment in the Local Group. We followed up with ESO VLT/UVES spectra of the most metal- poor star known in this (or any external) galaxy, AS0039.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02761v1.title: The Andromeda Galaxy's Last Major Merger: Constraints from the survey of Planetary Nebulae
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02761v1.summary: The Andromeda galaxy (M 31) has experienced a tumultuous merger history. We identify the older dynamically hotter thicker disc in M 31 and a distinct younger dynamically colder thin disc. The two discs are alsochemically distinct with the PN chemodynamics implying their formation in a wet major merger (mass ratio ~1:5) 2.5-4.5 Gyr ago.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02755v1.title: Star Formation History of the Small Magellanic Cloud: the shell substructure
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02755v1.summary: We present the spatially resolved star formation history (SFH) of ashell-like structure located in the northeastern Small Magellanic Cloud (SMC) We find young star formationenhancements at ~150 Myr, ~200 Myr,~450 Myr, 650 Myr, and ~1 Gyr.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14151v3.title: The survey of planetary nebulae in Andromeda (M31) VI. Kinematics of M31 inner-halo substructures and comparison with major-merger simulation predictions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.14151v3.summary: M31 has experienced a recent tumultuous merger history as evidenced from the many substructures that are still present in its inner halo. The G1-Clump, NE- and W- shelves, and the Giant Stream (GS) were formed in a single unique event.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02713v1.title: Seen and unseen: bursty star formation and its implications for observations of high-redshift galaxies with JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02713v1.summary: We examine the Implications of bursty star formation histories for observations of high-redshift galaxies with JWST. We find the galaxy observability to be highly time-dependent for galaxies near the survey's limit. We also investigate selection effects due to burstyStar formation on the physical properties measured, such as the gas fraction, specific star formation rate, and metallicity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02703v1.title: JWST constraints on the UV luminosity density at cosmic dawn: implications for 21-cm cosmology
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02703v1.summary: JWST observations for radio experiments aimed at detecting the redshifted 21-cm hyperfine transition of diffuse neutral hydrogen. A high star formation efficiency at early times may trigger the onset of intense Ly$\alpha$ emission at redshift. This could produce a cosmic 21- cm absorption signal 200 Myr after the Big Bang.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02701v1.title: Star cluster progenitors are dynamically decoupled from their parent self-gravitating molecular clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02701v1.summary: The formation of stellar clusters dictates the pace at which galaxies evolve. Solving the question of their formation will undoubtedly lead to a better understanding of the Universe as a whole. Findings suggest that the formation of star clusters correspond to a transition regime within the properties of the self-gravitating molecular gas.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.13146v3.title: iMaNGA: mock MaNGA galaxies based on IllustrisTNG and MaStar SSPs -- II. The catalogue
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.13146v3.summary: We build the iMaNGA catalogue from the TNG50 cosmological simulations. We also investigate our ability to recover the galaxy kinematics andstellar population properties with full-spectral fitting. We conclude that our mock generation and spectral fitting processes do not distort the `intrinsic' galaxy properties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02676v1.title: A complete catalogue of broad-line AGNs and double-peaked emission lines from MaNGA integral-field spectroscopy of 10K galaxies: stellar population of AGNs, supermassive black holes, and dual AGNs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02676v1.summary: We identify 188 galaxies for which the emission lines cannot be described by single Gaussian components. The catalogue helps us further understand the AGN-galaxy coevolution through the stellar population of broad-line region host galaxies. We use the broad-$H\alpha$line width and luminosity to estimate masses of black hole in these galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02550v1.title: The impact of effective matter mixing based on three-dimensional hydrodynamical models on the molecule formation in the ejecta of SN 1987A
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02550v1.summary: Time-dependent rate equations for chemical reactions are solved for one-zone and one-dimensional ejecta models of SN 1987A. One-dimensional profiles obtained byangle-averaging of the three-dimensional hydrodynamical models reflect the 3D matter mixing. Compton electrons produced by the decay of $^{56}$Ni could ionize atoms and molecules and could destruct molecules.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02514v1.title: Variability of Young Stellar Objects in the Perseus Molecular Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02514v1.summary: We present an analysis of 288 young stellar objects (YSOs) in the Perseus Molecular Cloud that have well defined $g$ and $r$-band lightcurves. Of the 288 YSOs, 238 sources (83% of our working sample) are identified as variables based on the normalized peak-to-peak                variability metric.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02478v1.title: Galaxy Morphology from $z\sim6$ through the eyes of JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02478v1.summary: We analyze the Near Infrared ($\sim0.8-1\mu$m) rest-frame morphologies of galaxies with redshift $0<z<6$ in the CEERS survey. For small (large) and faint objects, JWST-based classifications systematically present less bulge-dominated systems (peculiar galaxies) than HST- based ones.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02453v1.title: Carbon Stars as Standard Candles: An Empirical Test for the Reddening, Metallicity, and Age Sensitivity of the J-region Asymptotic Giant Branch (JAGB) Method
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02453v1.summary: The J-region Asymptotic Giant Branch (JAGB) method is a standard candle based on the intrinsic luminosities of carbon stars in the near infrared. For the first time, we directly constrain the impact of metallicity, age, and reddening on the JAGB method.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02443v1.title: The Long and the Short of It: The Benefits and Leverage of Ultraviolet-Radio Galaxy Fitting
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02443v1.summary: The far ultraviolet (FUV) to far-infrared (FIR) energy distributions (SEDs) of galaxies have been considered separately despite the common physical process shaping them. In this work, we explore the utility of simultaneously fitting FUV-radio SEDs using an extended version of the ProSpect SED fitting code. We find that for situations where MIR-FIR photometry is unavailable, including a 1.4 GHz continuum measurement allows for improved accuracy in recovered star formation rates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.13103v2.title: Influence of turbulence on Lyman-alpha scattering
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.13103v2.summary: We develop a Monte Carlo radiative transfer code to study the effect of turbulence with a finite correlation length on scattering of Lyman-alpha(Ly$\alpha$) photons propagating through neutral atomic hydrogen gas. We find that the correlation length is an important and sensitive parameter that has an influence on physically relevant properties of radiativetransfer. In particular, it can significantly, by orders of magnitude, reduce the number of scattering events that the averageLy$ \alpha$ photon undergoes before it escapes the turbulent cloud.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.00373v2.title: Photometric IGM tomography with Subaru/HSC: the large-scale structure of Ly$α$ emitters and IGM transmission in the COSMOS field at $z\sim5$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.00373v2.summary: "Photometric IGM tomography" is a novel technique to map theIntergalactic medium (IGM) at $z\simeq4.9$ in the COSMOS field. It utilizes deep narrow-band imaging to detect faint Ly$\alpha$ forest transmission in background galaxies across the Subaru/Hyper-Suprime Cam's field of view.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.12951v3.title: Constraints on Yukawa gravity parameters from observations of bright stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.12951v3.summary: In 2020 the GRAVITY Collaboration detected the orbital precession of the S2 star around the supermassive black hole (SMBH) The precessions can be fitted by Yukawa gravity. We analyze S-star orbits assuming differentstrength of Yukawa interaction and find that this parameter has strong influence.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02358v1.title: Are all metal-poor stars of second-generation?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02358v1.summary: The Milky Way stellar halo is one of the oldest and most metal-poor component of the Local Group. A peculiar class of stars, the so-calledCarbon-Enhanced Metal-Poor (CEMP-no) stars, seem to be directly related to Pop III stars. We find that only the most C-enhanced and Fe-poor stars enclose the pure imprint of Pop III.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02353v1.title: Witnessing the intracluster medium assembly at the cosmic noon in JKCS041
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02353v1.summary: JKCS041 has a low central pressure and a low Compton Y compared to local clusters selected by their intracluster medium. It is likely because the cluster is still in the process of assembly but also in part because of a hard-to-quantify bias in current local ICM-selected samples.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02352v1.title: Time variability of ultra-fast BAL outflows using SALT: C IV equivalent width analysis
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02352v1.summary: Time variability of ultra-fast outflows (UFOs) detected in a sample of 64 C IV broad absorption line (BAL) quasars monitored using the Southern African LargeTelescope. BALs with low W, high-velocity, shallow profiles, and low-vel velocity width tend to show more variability.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02346v1.title: Evidence of First Stars-enriched Gas in High-redshift Absorbers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02346v1.summary: The first stars were born from chemically pristine gas. They were likelymassive, and thus they rapidly exploded as supernovae. They enriched the surrounding gas with the first heavy elements. In the Local Group, the chemicalsignatures of the first stellar population were identified among low-mass, long-lived, very metal-poor stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02347v1.title: HYPerluminous quasars at the Epoch of ReionizatION (HYPERION). A new regime for the X-ray nuclear properties of the first quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02347v1.summary: The existence of luminous quasars (QSO) at the Epoch of Reionization (EoR;.e. z>6) challenges models of early SMBH formation. To shed light on the nature of these sources we started a multiwavelength programme based on a sample of 18 HYPerluminous QSOs at the EoR.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02344v1.title: Inspiraling streams of enriched gas observed around a massive galaxy 11 billion years ago
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02344v1.summary: Stars form in galaxies, from gas that has been accreted from theintergalactic medium. Simulations have shown that recycling of gas-thereaccretion of gas that was previously ejected from a galaxy-could sustain starformation in the early Universe. We observe the gas surrounding a massive                galaxy at redshift 2.3 and detect emission lines from neutral hydrogen, helium,                and ionized carbon that extend 100 kiloparsecs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.02335v1.title: Over-massive Central Black Holes in the Cosmological Simulations ASTRID and Illustris TNG50
