http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19319v1.title: The far side of the Galactic bulge revealed through semi-regular variables
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19319v1.summary: The structure andkinematics of the bulge/bar beyond the Galactic center have remained largelyunexplored. We present a method to measure distances of luminous red                giants using a period-amplitude-luminosity relation. We show that distance uncertainty plays a major factor in the alignment of the major and kinematic axes of the bar and bulge.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19318v1.title: Gravitational Waves from Black-Hole Encounters: Prospects for Ground- and Galaxy-Based Observatories
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19318v1.summary: Close hyperbolic encounters of black holes (BHs) generate certain Burst WithMemory (BWM) events in the frequency windows of gravitational wave observatories. We present detailedexplorations of the detectable parameter space of such events that are relevant for the LIGO-Virgo-KAGRA and the International Pulsar Timing Array (IPTA)consortia.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19315v1.title: TRINITY III: Quasar Luminosity Functions Decomposed by Halo, Galaxy, and Black Hole Masses and Eddington Ratios from z=0-10
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19315v1.summary: We present the redshift evolution of quasar luminosity functions decomposed by halo mass, galaxy mass, supermassive black hole (SMBH) mass, and Eddingtonratio. We also present SMBH kinetic/radiative energy output ratios from TRINITY, aflexible empirical model that self-consistently infers the halo--galaxy--S MBH connection that match observational data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19310v1.title: The Merian Survey: Design, Construction, and Characterization of a Filter Set Optimized to Find Dwarf Galaxies and Measure their Dark Matter Halo Properties with Weak Lensing
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19310v1.summary: The Merian survey is mapping the first high signal-to-noise (S/N) measure of weak gravitational lensing around dwarf galaxies. With 60 full nights on the Blanco/Dark Energy Camera, the survey is predicted to measure the average weak lensing profile. This unprecedented sample will allow for studies of the interplay between dark matter and stellar feedback.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19312v1.title: Reversing the verdict: cataclysmic variables could be the dominant progenitors of AM CVn binaries after all
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19312v1.summary: AM CVn binaries are systems in which a white dwarf accretes matter from a helium-rich (semi-)degenerate object. For a long time, it has been believed that these systems cannotdescend from cataclysmic variables (CVs), at least not in large numbers, because the initial conditions need to be fine-tuned.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19192v1.title: GMCs and their Type classification in M74: Toward understanding star formation and cloud evolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19192v1.summary: We investigated the giant molecular clouds (GMCs) in M74 (NGC 628) obtained by the PHANGS project. In total, 432 GMCs were identified, where theindividual GMC Types are 65, 203, and 164, for Type I, Type II, and Type III,respectively. The size and mass of the GMCs range from 23 - 237 pc, showing a trend that mass and radius progressively increase from Type I to II to III.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19177v1.title: Interpreting the Si II and C II line spectra from the COS Legacy Spectroscopic SurveY using a virtual galaxy from a high-resolution radiation-hydrodynamic simulation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19177v1.summary: This work investigates how mock spectra generated using a single galaxy in aradiation-hydrodynamical simulation can help us interpret observations. We create 22,500 C II and Si II spectra from the virtual galaxy at different times and through multiple lines of sight. We find that the mock profiles provide accuratereplicates to the observations of 38 galaxies with a broad range of stellar masses and metallicities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.10011v1.title: Synchrotron Intensity Gradient Revealing Magnetic Fields in Galaxy Clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.10011v1.summary: Magnetic fields and their dynamical interplay with matter in galaxy clusters contribute to the physical properties and evolution of the intracluster medium. The current understanding of the origin and properties of cluster magnetic fields is still limited by observational challenges. In this article, we map the magnetic fields at hundreds-kpc scales of five clusters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.10010v1.title: Damping of MHD Turbulence in A Partially Ionized Medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.10010v1.summary: Ions and neutrals in the interstellar medium play a key role in the dynamics of magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) turbulence. We investigate the damping of MHD turbulence using 3D two-fluid simulations generated with the AthenaK code. We find density fluctuations in ions can be enhanced when neutral and                ions are weakly coupled.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.10005v1.title: Nature of Striation in 21 cm Channel Maps: Velocity Caustics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.10005v1.summary: The alignment of striated intensity structures in thin neutral hydrogen (HI) channels with Galactic magnetic fields has been observed. We show that velocity caustics can cause a correlation between unsharp-masked HI structures and far-infrared emission. We conclude that similar to the Velocity Channel Gradients (VChGs) approach, RHT traces magnetic fields through the analysis of velocity caistics in thin channels.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.00049v2.title: Spatially resolved self-consistent spectral modelling of jellyfish galaxies from MUSE with FADO: trends with mass and stripping intensity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.00049v2.summary: We present a spatially resolved stellar population analysis of 61 jellyfish grotesquegalaxies and 47 control galaxies observed with ESO/MUSE. We find that "extreme stripping" and "stripping" galaxies are typically younger than the other types. The ages of the most massive galaxies become similar to or lower than the ages of lower mass ones.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09924v1.title: Cosmic ray processes in galactic ecosystems
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09924v1.summary: Galaxy evolution is an important topic, and our physical understanding must be complete to establish a correct picture. The effects of CRs are yet to be fully comprehended, and their complex multi-channel feedback mechanisms pose a significant technical challenge. We presentrecent advancements in our understanding of CR processes and interpretation of their signatures.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09857v1.title: Measurement of size of gamma-ray source in blazar B0218+357 from microlensing at 100 GeV energy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09857v1.summary: The effect of microlensing in gravitationally lensed quasars can be used to study the structure of active galactic nuclei on distance scales. We combine observations of abright flare of the source in 2014 with Fermi/LAT and MAGIC telescopes in the 0.1-100 GeV energy range.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09854v1.title: Searching for Milky Way twins: Radial abundance distribution as a strict criterion
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09854v1.summary: We search for Milky Way-like galaxies among a sample of approximately 500galaxies. The characteristics we considered of the candidate galaxies are the following: stellar mass M_star, optical radius R_25, rotation velocity V_rot, central oxygen abundance (O/H)_0, and abundance at the optical radius(O/h)_R25. We find that the position of the Milky Way on the (O-H-R25 diagram shows a large deviation from the general trend.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09845v1.title: Exploring the origin of the extended main sequence turn off in M37 through the white dwarf cooling sequence
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09845v1.summary: New observations from the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope to study the white dwarf cooling sequence of the open cluster M37. M37 displays an extended main sequence turn-off and, according to a recent photometricanalysis, also a spread of initial chemical composition. By taking advantage of first epoch collected in 1999 with the same telescope, we have been able to calculate proper motions for sources as faint as g ~ 26.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09829v1.title: X-ray Cavity Dynamics and their Role in the Gas Precipitation in Planck Sunyaev-Zeldovich (SZ) Selected Clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09829v1.summary: We study active galactic nucleus (AGN) feedback in nearby galaxy clusters. Relaxed clusters better follow the one-to-one relation of cavity power. Disturbed clusters display higher cavity power for a given cooling luminosity. We found clusters with short central cooling times, tcool, contain warm ionized gas.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07936v2.title: Galaxy cluster rotation revealed in the MACSIS simulations with the kinetic Sunyaev-Zeldovich effect
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07936v2.summary: The kinetic Sunyaev-Zeldovich (kSZ) effect has now become a clear target for studies of the cosmic microwave background (CMB) and cosmology. The rotational kSZ effect is caused by coherent large-scale motions of the cluster medium using cluster hydrodynamic simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09661v1.title: The Intrinsic Alignment of Galaxy Clusters and Impact of Projection Effects
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09661v1.summary: Galaxy clusters exhibit the strongest alignment with the large-scale structure. However, mis-identificationof members due to projection effects from the large scale structure can occur. We studied the impact of projection effects on the measurement of the intrinsicalignment of galaxy clusters, using galaxy cluster mock catalogs. Our findings showed that projection effects result in a decrease of the largescale alignment signal of the cluster.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09630v1.title: The MAGPI Survey: Impact of environment on the total internal mass distribution of galaxies in the last 5 Gyr
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09630v1.summary: We investigate the impact of environment on the internal mass distribution of galaxies. We use 2D resolved stellar kinematics to construct dynamical models for galaxies at mean redshift $z \sim 0.3$ We find a median density slope of -2.22% for galaxies in the Middle Ages Galaxy Properties (MAGPI) survey.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.10749v2.title: Growth or Decay -- I: universality of the turbulent dynamo saturation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.10749v2.summary: The turbulent small-scale dynamo (SSD) is likely to be responsible for the Magnetisation of the interstellar medium. Usually, this process is studied by initialising a weak seed magnetic field and letting the turbulence grow it to saturation. We show that the final saturated state of the turbulent dynamo is set by the turbulence and the material properties of the plasma, independent of the initial structure of the magnetic field.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08356v2.title: Tidal Spin-up of Black Hole Progenitor Stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.08356v2.summary: Gravitational wave observations indicate the existence of merging black holes(BHs) with high spin. A possible way to form those binaries is through the tidalspin-up of a Wolf-Rayet (WR) star by its BH companion. Tidal spin-up in lower-mass systems is more efficient.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09570v1.title: Physical Conditions and Extension of the Coronal Line Region in IC 5063
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09570v1.summary: We study the ionised and highly ionised gas phases in the Seyfert~2 galaxy                IC~5063 by means of VLT/MUSE integral field spectroscopy. Our analysis allowed us to detect a high-ionisation gas outflow traced by the coronal lines. Both emissions are found to be extended. The former up to 1.2~kpc and 700~pc NW and SE from the nucleus.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.02056v3.title: A spatially resolved analysis of star-formation burstiness by comparing UV and H$α$ in galaxies at z$\sim$1 with UVCANDELS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.02056v3.summary: The UltraViolet imaging of the Cosmic Assembly Near-infrared Deep.Extragalactic Legacy Survey Fields (UVCANDELS) program provides HST/UVIS F275Wimaging for four CANDELS fields. We combine this UV imaging with existing.HST/near-IR grism spectroscopy from 3D-HST$+$AGHAST to directly compare. the average UV-to-H$\alpha$ luminosity as a function of galaxy radius.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08975v2.title: Expectations for time-delay measurements in active galactic nuclei with the Vera Rubin Observatory
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08975v2.summary: The Vera Rubin Observatory will provide an unprecedented set of time-dependent observations of the sky. We show that time delays for emission lines can be well measured from the Main Survey for the bright tail of the quasar distribution with the accuracy within 1 sigma error. We see a systematic offset between the assumed and recovered time delay depending on the redshift and source luminosity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09502v1.title: The Dark Neutral Medium is (Mostly) Molecular Hydrogen
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09502v1.summary: We acquired ALMA ground state absorption profiles of HCO+ and other molecules toward the Galactic anticenter. N(H2) and N(DNM) are strongly correlated and vary by factors of 50-100 over the observed range EBV~0.05-1 mag, while N(HI) varies by only 2-3. HCO+. absorption was detected in 28 of 33 new directions and CO emission along 19 of those.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09414v1.title: Optimizing Roman's High Latitude Wide Area Survey for Low Surface Brightness Astronomy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09414v1.summary: One of the last remaining frontiers in optical/near-infrared observationalastronomy is the low surface brightness regime. Studying this domain promises to be transformative for our understanding of star formation in low-mass galaxies. The High Latitude Wide Area Survey offers a unique opportunity to statistically study the LSB universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09404v1.title: When the Well Runs Dry: Modeling Environmental Quenching in Massive Clusters at $\boldsymbol z \gtrsim 1$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09404v1.summary: We explore models of satellite quenching in massive clusters at $z\gtrsim1$ using an MCMC framework. We find that they can be separated between "starvation" and "core quenched"scenarios. The starvation pathway is characterized by satellites with relatively high line-of-sight velocities that quench on short timescales.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09407v1.title: Evidence for baryon acoustic oscillations from galaxy-ellipticity correlations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09407v1.summary: The Baryon Acoustic Oscillations (BAO) feature in the clustering of galaxies or quasars provides a "standard ruler" for distance measurements in cosmology. We measure the GI correlation functions and model them using the linear alignment model. We constrain the distance from redshift $0.57$ to a precision of $3\sim5\%$.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09398v1.title: Formation of Galactic Disks I: Why did the Milky Way's Disk Form Unusually Early?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09398v1.summary: The stellar disk of our Milky Way was formed quite early, within the first few billion years of its evolution. Chemo-kinematic signatures of disk formation in cosmological zoom-in simulations appear to be in tension with these data. We investigate the formation of galactic disks using arepresentative sample of MW-like galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09403v1.title: Breaking degeneracies in the first galaxies with clustering
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09403v1.summary: UVLF has become essential for understanding the formation and evolution of the first galaxies. Yet, UVLFs only measure galaxy abundances, giving rise to a degeneracy between the meangalaxy luminosity and its stochasticity. New clustering measurements with the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) and Roman, will be able to break this degeneracy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09319v1.title: Decoding the age-chemical structure of the Milky Way disk: An application of Copulas and Elicitable Maps
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09319v1.summary: In the Milky Way, the distribution of stars in the $[\alpha/\mathrm{Fe}]$ vs. age planes holds essential information about the history of star formation, accretion, and dynamicalevolution of the Galactic disk. We investigate these planes by applying novel.statistical methods called copulas and elicitable maps to the ages and.abundances of red giants in the APOGEE survey.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09311v1.title: Millimeter Observations of the Type II SN2023ixf: Constraints on the Proximate Circumstellar Medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09311v1.summary: We present 1.3 mm (230 GHz) observations of the recent and nearby Type IIsupernova, SN2023ixf, obtained with the Submillimeter Array (SMA) at 2.6-18.6 days after explosion. The observations were obtained as part of the SMA Large Program POETS (Pursuit of Extragalactic Transients with SMA) We do not detect any emission at the location of SN20 23ixf.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.06902v2.title: COOL-LAMPS IV: A Sample of Bright Strongly-Lensed Galaxies at $3 < z < 4$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.06902v2.summary: We report the discovery of five bright strong gravitationally lensed galaxies at $3 < z < 4$: COOLJ0101$+$2055 ($z = 3.459$), COOL J0104$-$0757 ($z= 3.480$),COOLJ0516$-$2208 ($z < 3.549$), and COOL j1356$+ $0339 ($z + 3.753$). These galaxies have magnitudes of $r_{\rm AB}, $rz_ AB, and are lensed by galaxy clusters at $

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09395v1.title: Tracing the green valley with entropic thresholding
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09395v1.summary: The green valley represents the population of galaxies that are transitioning from the actively star-forming blue cloud to the passively evolving red sequence. Studying the properties of the green valley galaxies is crucial for understanding the exact mechanisms and processes that drive this transition. The green valley does not have a universally accepted definition.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.17045v2.title: Strong Outflows and Inefficient Star Formation in the Reionization-era Ultra-faint Dwarf Galaxy Eridanus II
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.17045v2.summary: We present novel constraints on the underlying galaxy formation physics at the Local Group. We find that the evolution of Eri II is well-characterized by a short, exponentially declining star-formation history. We make predictions for the distribution of [Mg/Fe] and [Fe/H] in Ei II as well as the prevalence of ultra-metal-poor stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09195v1.title: Broadband X-ray Spectral Study of Nuclear Structure in Local Obscured Radio Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09195v1.summary: Radio galaxies are a key population to understand the importance ofrelativistic jets in AGN feedback. We present the results of a systematic,broadband X-ray spectral analysis of six radio galaxies to investigate their nuclear structures. We find that these radio galaxies have similar torus covering fractions compared with radio quiet AGNs at the same Eddington ratios.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09142v1.title: GN-z11: The environment of an AGN at $z=$10.603
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09142v1.summary: GN-z11 is one of the most distant galaxies identified with the Hubble Space Telescope. It lies in a large-scale, overdense structure with possible Population III (PopIII) stars in its halo. Surprisingly, Ly$\alpha$ has also been detected despite the expected largely neutralinter-galactic medium at such a redshift.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09133v1.title: New Dimensions of Galactic Chemical Evolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09133v1.summary: Dramatic progress in understanding galactic chemical evolution (GCE) has been driven partly by direct observations of the distant past with HST and JWST. I discuss (1) the interleaved but distinguishable but galactic scale astrophysics. I also discuss the dimensionality of the stellar distribution of chemical abundance space.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09071v1.title: An overview of desorption parameters of Volatile and Complex Organic Molecules: A systematic dig on experimental literature
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09071v1.summary: Desorption energy and pre-exponential frequency factor are essential to describe the desorption of molecules. Experimental determinations of these parameters are missing for many molecules, including those found in the interstellar medium. The Redhead-TST method is found to provide reliable results that agree well with more rigorous experimental methods.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09031v1.title: Exploring Stellar Cluster and Feedback-driven Star Formation in Galactic Mid-infrared Bubble [HKS2019] E70
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09031v1.summary: The E70 bubble is embedded in the Galactic mid-infrared (MIR) cloud and hosts massive stars as well as young stellar objects(YSOs) The spectral type of the brightest star 'M1' of the E70 cluster is estimated as O9V. A low-density shell-like structure in 12 CO(J=1-0) molecular emission along the perimeter of the bubble.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.11668v2.title: Searching for Spectroscopic Signatures of Ongoing Quenching in SDSS Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.11668v2.summary: This paper estimates the current SFR relative to the average during the last 800                Myr, for 300'000 galaxies selected from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey. The goals are to examine, in a much larger and independent sample, the trends previously reported in a sample of star-forming MaNGA galaxies, and also to search for spectroscopic signatures of ongoing quenching.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08883v1.title: The Spectacular Tidal Tails of Globular Cluster M3 (NGC 5272)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08883v1.summary: We provide a detailed analysis on tidal tails of the globular cluster M3. We first discover clear extra-tidal structures with slight S-shape near the cluster. This inspires us to examine the existence of its long tidal tails. We estimate stream width, star number density and surface brightness for both tails, as well as the distance variation along the entire stream.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04308v2.title: Faint Galaxy Number Counts in the Durhamand SDSS Catalogues
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04308v2.summary: The Durham Extragalactic Astronomy and Cosmology catalogue could be well-fitted over their whole range using luminosity function (LF) parameters derived from the SDSS. A cosmological model treating Hubble expansion as an Einstein curvature required less correction at faint magnitudes than a $\Lambda$CDM model.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06317v2.title: The DESI One-Percent survey: constructing galaxy-halo connections for ELGs and LRGs using auto and cross correlations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06317v2.summary: In current Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI) survey, emission line grotesquegalaxies (ELGs) and luminous red galaxies (LRGs) are essential for mapping dark matter distribution. We measure the auto and cross correlationfunctions of ELGs and LRGs at $0.8<z\leq 1.0$ from the DESI One-Percent survey. With the stellar-halo mass relation (SHMR) for thewhole galaxy population (i.e. normal galaxies), LRGs can be directly selected according to the stellar mass. ELGs can also be selected

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.14048v2.title: Nuclear and electromagnetic cascades induced by ultrahigh-energy cosmic rays in radio galaxies: implications for Centaurus A
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.14048v2.summary: Very-high-energy (VHE) and neutrinos are crucial for identifying accelerators of ultrahigh- energy cosmic rays (UHECRs) We develop a numerical code to solve the transport equation for UHECR nuclei and their secondaries. In particular, we focus on Centaurus A, which has been proposed as one of the most promising UH ECR sources in the local universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03127v2.title: Improved Modeling of the Kinematic Sunyaev-Zel'dovich Projected-Fields signal and its Cosmological Dependence
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03127v2.summary: The kinematic Sunyaev-Zel'dovich (kSZ) effect has evolved as an observational probe of the distribution of baryons and velocityfields in the late Universe. The current theoretical modeling of this effect involves an approximate treatment only applicable at small scale. We show that the differences between the predicted signal from the two models are scale-dependent.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08710v1.title: The variable stars in the field of NGC 6139: A critical approach to their reddening and membership
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08710v1.summary: We present a CCD $VI$ time-series analysis of the globular cluster NGC 6139. We report two clustermember RRc (V12, V15) and four SR (V13, V14, V17, V18) not previously detected. The Oosterhoff type II nature of the cluster is confirmed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.16577v2.title: Lopsided Galaxies in a cosmological context: a new galaxy-halo connection
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.16577v2.summary: Disc galaxies commonly show asymmetric features in their morphology, such as warps and lopsidedness. In the nearby Universe, up to 30 percent of late-type galaxies display a global non-axisymmetric mass distribution. The origin of this perturbation is not yet well understood.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08684v1.title: An Extended Catalogue of galaxy morphology using Deep Learning in Southern Photometric Local Universe Survey Data Release 3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08684v1.summary: Deep Learning (DL) based morphological catalog built from images obtained by the Southern Photometric Local Universe Survey (S-PLUS) The method achieves an precision rate of 98.5$\%$ in distinguishing between spiral, as part of the larger category oflate type (LT) galaxies, and elliptical, belonging to early type (ET) galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08679v1.title: Heating Galaxy Clusters with Interacting Dark Matter
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08679v1.summary: Overcooling of cool core clusters is a persistent puzzle in theastrophysics of galaxy clusters. We propose that it may naturally be resolvedvia interactions between the baryons of the intracluster medium (ICM) and itsdark matter (DM) DM-baryon interactions can inject heat into the ICM to offset cooling.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08678v1.title: A Luminous Red Supergiant and Dusty Long-period Variable Progenitor for SN 2023ixf
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08678v1.summary: We analyze pre-explosion near- and mid-infrared (IR) imaging of the site of SN 2023ixf in the nearby spiral galaxy M101. The star displays compelling evidence of variability with a period of $1000 days and an amplitude of 0.6 mag. We estimate the pre-SN mass-loss rate of the star between 3-19 years before explosion.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08677v1.title: Galactic ArchaeoLogIcaL ExcavatiOns (GALILEO) II. t-SNE Portrait of Local Fossil Relics and Structures
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08677v1.summary: Based on high-quality APOGEE DR17 and Gaia DR3 data for 1,742 red giants within 5 kpc of the Sun and not rotating with the Galactic disc. Seven structures are detected, including the Splash, Gaia-Sausage-Enceladus (GSE), N-C-O peculiar stars, and innerdisk-like stars. Two groups that did not match anything previouslyreported in the literature, here named Galileo 5 and Galileo 6 (G5 and G6)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08674v1.title: Densities and mass assembly histories of the Milky Way satellites are not a challenge to $Λ$CDM
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08674v1.summary: We use the \texttt{GRUMPY} galaxy formation model based on a suite of high-resolution, dissipationless Cold Dark Matter simulations. We show that observed MW dwarf satellites exhibit a trend of decreasing density with increasing stellar mass. None of theobserved satellites are overly dense compared to the results of our model.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08646v1.title: New Active Galactic Nuclei Detected by the ART-XC and eROSITA Telescopes during the First Five SRG All-Sky X-ray Surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08646v1.summary: 14 sources are reliably detected by the SRG/eROSITA telescope in the 0.2-8.keV energy band. Six of them have been detected in X-rays for the first time, while the remaining ones have already been known previously as X-ray sources. We have taken optical spectra for 12 sources with the 1.6-m AZT-33IK telescope at the Sayan Observatory.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.05757v2.title: Terrestrial Effects of Nearby Supernovae: Updated Modeling
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.05757v2.summary: We have reevaluated recent studies of the effects on Earth by cosmic rays from nearby supernovae (SNe) at 100 and 50 pc. Inclusion of this suppression leads to lower atmospheric ionization, smaller ozone depletion, and lower sea-level muon radiation doses. Overall, our results indicate that, considering only the effects of CRs, the "lethal" SN distance should be closer to 20 pc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07371v2.title: A Global Semi-Analytic Model of the First Stars and Galaxies Including Dark Matter Halo Merger Histories
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07371v2.summary: We present a new self-consistent semi-analytic model of the first stars and galaxies. Our model includes the detailed mergerhistory of dark matter halos generated with Monte Carlo merger trees. We find an overall increase in the resulting star formation rate density compared to calibrations based on previous simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.00775v2.title: Quasi-periodic eruptions from impacts between the secondary and a rigidly precessing accretion disc in an extreme mass-ratio inspiral system
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.00775v2.summary: X-ray quasi-periodic eruptions (QPEs) represent a recently discovered example of extreme X-ray variability associated with supermassive black holes. These high-amplitude bursts recurring every few hours are detected in the soft X-rays from nearby galaxies. The physical origin of this new phenomenon is still unknown.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08605v1.title: Near-infrared emission line diagnostics for AGN from the local Universe to redshift 3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08605v1.summary: Optical rest-frame spectroscopic diagnostics are usually employed to distinguish between star formation and AGN-powered emission. However, this method is biased against dusty sources, hampering a complete census of the AGNpopulation across cosmic epochs. To mitigate this effect, it is crucial to observe at longer wavelengths in the rest- frame near-infrared (near-IR), which is less affected by dust attenuation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04017v2.title: Understanding the progenitor formation galaxies of merging binary black holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04017v2.summary: With nearly a hundred gravitational wave detections, the origin of black hole mergers has become a key question. Here, we focus on understanding the typicalgalactic environment in which binary black Hole mergers arise. We find that over 50% of BBH mergers have a progenitor metallicity of a few tenths of Solar metalicity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08578v1.title: Stellar clustering and the kinematics of stars around Collinder 121 using Gaia DR3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08578v1.summary: Collinder 121 lies in the region of Canis Majorcentred around l = 236 degrees, b = -10 degrees. Using Gaia DR3 data, we do not find associations at the distances given in the literature. Instead, using the HDBSCAN machine learning algorithm, we find a major association of OB stars centred around 803 pc. Within this association we find four smaller subgroups that may be indicative of a larger OB group.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.09510v2.title: First Light and Reionisation Epoch Simulations (FLARES) X: Environmental Galaxy Bias and Survey Variance at High Redshift
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.09510v2.summary: Upcoming deep galaxy surveys with JWST will probe galaxy evolution during theepoch of reionisation. Star formation is highly biasedrelative to the underlying dark matter distribution. galaxies in the EoR are highly clustered, which can lead to large variance in survey number counts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.09396v3.title: Cosmological structure formation in complex scalar field dark matter versus real ultralight axions: a comparative study using CLASS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.09396v3.summary: Calculating the evolution of the background Universe, as well as linearperturbations, focusing on scalar modes. We consider models with complex scalar field with a repulsive, quartic self-interaction (SI), and models without SI. The mild falloff in the SFDM power spectrum toward high k is similar to that of CDM.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08540v1.title: Keck Spectroscopy of NGC 1052-DF9: Stellar Populations in the Context of the NGC 1052 Group
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08540v1.summary: Three galaxies are proposed constituents of a trail of galaxies recently hypothesised to have formed as part of a ''bullet dwarf'' collision. We show that the ages and total metallicities of the three galaxies are within uncertainties of one another. We conclude further work is required to understand theformation of this interesting group of galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08539v1.title: Streamers feeding the SVS13-A protobinary system: astrochemistry reveals accretion shocks?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08539v1.summary: We report ALMA high-angular resolution (~ 50 au) observations of the binary system SVS13-A. We analyse deuterated water (HDO) and sulfur                dioxide (SO2) emission. We propose that the observed emission is produced by an accretion shock at the interface between the accretion streamer and disk of VLA4A.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.03699v3.title: Quantifying the energetics of molecular superbubbles in PHANGS galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.03699v3.summary: When young, massive stars form in spatially clustered environments, they create pockets of expanding gas called superbubbles. We measure their radii and expansion velocities using CO to derive their ages and the mechanical power driving the bubbles. We also combine the properties of the stellar populations with CO to constrain feedback models and quantify their energetics.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08471v1.title: The Dynamics and Energetics of Remnant and Restarting RLAGN
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08471v1.summary: In this article, I review past, current, and future advances in the study of radio-loud galaxies. I focus on their dynamics and population statistics. I also discuss the prospects of future discoveries that may shed further light on these elusive subpopulations of RLAGN.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08446v1.title: M Giants with IGRINS II. Chemical Evolution of Fluorine at High Metallicities
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08446v1.summary: The origin and evolution of fluorine in the Milky Way galaxy is still in debate. In particular, the increase of the [F/Fe] in metal-rich stars found from near-IR HF-lines is challenging to explain theoretically. Based on adetailed line-by-line analysis of ten HF lines, we find that the R19, R18 and R16 lines should primarily be used for abundance analysis.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08443v1.title: Determination of the Spiral Pattern Speed in the Galaxy from Three Samples of Stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08443v1.summary: We invoke the estimates of the amplitudes of the velocity perturbations caused by the influence of a spiral density wave that have been obtained by us previously from three stellar samples. The corotation radii for these three samples are $1.16\pm0.09-$1.15\/1.06$ suggesting that the corotation circle is located between the Sun and the Perseus arm segment.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10175v2.title: Measuring galaxy cluster mass profiles into the low acceleration regime with galaxy kinematics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10175v2.summary: We probe the dynamical mass profiles of 10 galaxy clusters using galaxy kinematics. We compare our derived dynamical masses with those calculated from X-ray gas data assuming hydrostatic equilibrium. Massive and rich relaxed clusters generally present consistent mass measurements. Unrelaxed or low-richness clusters have systematicallylarger total mass than hydrostatic mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08380v1.title: JWST Peers into the Class I Protostar TMC1A: Atomic Jet and Spatially Resolved Dissociative Shock Region
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08380v1.summary: Outflows and winds from young stars play a crucial role in the evolutionaryevolution of protostars and the early stages of planet formation. Details of the mechanism behind these phenomena are still debated. For the first time, acollimated atomic jet is detected from TMC1A in the [Fe II] line.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08376v1.title: Strange Quasar Candidates with Abnormal Astrometric Characteristics from Gaia EDR3 and SDSS (SQUAB-II): Optical Identifications
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08376v1.summary: There are some strange quasars with multiple Gaia detections or observed with abnormal astrometric characteristics. They could be potential candidates of quasar-star pairs, dual quasar (DQs), or lensed qu asars (LQs) We select 143 SDSS spectroscopically confirmedquasars that have multiple Gaia EDR3 detections.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.08504v2.title: Morphological Classification of Radio Galaxies with wGAN-supported Augmentation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.08504v2.summary: Machine learning techniques that perform morphological classification of.astronomical sources often suffer from a scarcity of labelled training data. We demonstrate the use of generativemodels, specifically Wasserstein GANs (wGANs), to generate data for different classes of radio galaxies. We find that this technique makes it possible to improve modelsfor the morphological classified of radio galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08346v1.title: Astrochemical models of interstellar ices: History matters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08346v1.summary: We model the formation of the main constituents of interstellar ices, including H2O, CO2 , CO, and CH3 OH. We first ran anastrochemical code for fixed conditions of temperature and density mapped in the cold core L429-C to benchmark the chemistry. In a second step, we simulated the chemical evolution of parcels of gas.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.06709v2.title: Satellite Observations of the Alfvénic Transition from Weak to Strong Magnetohydrodynamic Turbulence
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.06709v2.summary: Plasma turbulence is a ubiquitous dynamical process that transfers energyacross many spatial and temporal scales. Theory of anisotropic magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) has successfully described phenomena in nature. Core prediction of a transition from weak to strong MHD turbulence has not been observationally confirmed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08279v2.title: Terrestrial and Neptune mass free-floating planet candidates from the MOA-II 9-year Galactic Bulge survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08279v2.summary: We report the discoveries of low-mass free-floating planet (FFP) candidates. We found 6,111 microlensing candidates and identified a statistical sample of 3,535 high quality single lens events. The low detection efficiency for short duration events implies a large population of FFPs. One event, MOA-9y-5919, is the second terrestrial mass FFP candidate.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.11713v2.title: Subhalo abundance matching using progenitor mass at varying redshift: Two modes of stellar mass growth imprinted into the Subaru HSC galaxy clustering
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.11713v2.summary: We propose a novel subhalo abundance matching (SHAM) model. It uses the main progenitor of each (sub)halo as a proxy for the galaxy stellar mass. We find that the model can reproduce the observations very well over $10~h -1 mpc. We interpret trends as reflecting the downsizing in the in-situ star formation in lower-mass galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.01345v2.title: Big Three Dragons: Molecular Gas in a Bright Lyman-Break Galaxy at $z=7.15$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.01345v2.summary: We report ALMA Band 3 observations of CO(6-5), CO(7-6), and [CI](2-1) in B14-65666. The $3\sigma$ upper limits on the luminosities are approximately 40 times fainter than the [CII] luminosity. Despite this, we estimate a molecular gas-to-stellarmass ratio of $0.65-140$ and a gas depletion time of $2.5-550$ Myr.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08199v1.title: Observational implications of cosmologically coupled black holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08199v1.summary: "Cosmologically coupled" black holes with masses that increase in proportion to the volume of the Universe might be the physical basis of dark energy. We show that the number of black hole mergers would exceed the observed rate by orders of magnitude. Separately, if the mass growth happens at fixed angular momentum, the supermassive black holes in matter-deficient elliptical galaxies should be slowly rotating.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.03574v3.title: Magnetic Effects Promote Supermassive Star Formation in Metal-enriched Atomic-cooling Halos
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.03574v3.summary: Intermediate-mass black holes are promising candidates for the origin of supermassive black holes in the early universe. Chon & Omukai pointed out the direct collapse black hole (DCBH) formation in metal-enriched atomic-cooling halos. Hirano et al. (2021) showed that the magnetic effects promote the DCBH formation inMetal-free ACHs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08154v1.title: Search and study of ultracompact HII regions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08154v1.summary: We present results from a sample of 106 high-luminosity IRAS sources observed with the Very Large Array. 96 sources were observed in the X-band and 52 in the K-band, with 42 of them observed at both wavelengths. The detection rate of sources with 3.6~cm continuum emission was $\sim25\%$, while only 10\% have emission at 1.3~cm.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08150v1.title: SPYGLASS. IV. New Stellar Survey of Recent Star Formation within 1 kpc
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08150v1.summary: Young stellar populations provide a powerful record that traces millions of years of star formation history in the solar neighborhood. Using a revised form of the SPYGLASS young star identification methodology, we produce an expanded census of nearby young stars (Age $<50$ Myr) We then use the HDBSCAN clustering algorithm to produce a new SPyGLASS Catalog of Young Associations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11193v3.title: Implementation of Rare Isotopologues into Machine Learning of the Chemical Inventory of the Solar-Type Protostellar Source IRAS 16293-2422
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11193v3.summary: Machine learning techniques have been previously used to model and predict column densities in the TMC-1 dark molecular cloud. In interstellar sources, such as those where a protostar has been formed, the chemistry is known to be drastically different from that of largely quiescent dark clouds.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08143v1.title: On Stellar Migration from the Andromeda Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08143v1.summary: Recent Gaia observations suggest some hypervelocity stars (HVSs) might originate from outside the Galaxy. We ask if these HVSs could come from as far as Andromeda. We simulate HVS's originating in Andromeda with initial conditions based on attributes of high-velocity star measured in the Milky Way.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08120v1.title: The large molecular gas fraction of post-starburst galaxies at z > 1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08120v1.summary: Post-starburst galaxies are sources that had the last major episode of starformation about 1 Gyr before the epoch of the observations and are on their way to quiescence. It is important to study such galaxies at redshift z > 1, during their main quenching phase, and estimate their molecular gas content.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05472v2.title: Tidal Disruption Events from the Combined Effects of Two-Body Relaxation and the Eccentric Kozai-Lidov Mechanism
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05472v2.summary: Tidal disruption events (TDEs) take place when a star ventures too close to a supermassive black hole. Two-body relaxation and gravitational perturbations from an SMBH companion have been proposed as a promising stellar disruption channel. This combined channel produces disruptions at a rate that is consistent with observations and also naturally forms repeated TDEs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.01137v2.title: The breakdown of current gyrochronology as evidenced by old coeval stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.01137v2.summary: Gyrochronology can yield useful ages for field main-sequence stars. But constraints at older ages are scarce, making them potentially inaccurate and imprecise. We construct samples ofstellar pairs with coeval components, for a range of ages and with availablerotation periods.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04627v2.title: Inside the bubble: exploring the environments of reionisation-era Lyman-α emitting galaxies with JADES and FRESCO
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.04627v2.summary: We present a study of the environments of 16 Lyman-$\alpha$ emitting galaxies in the reionisation era. We conservatively estimate sizes of the ionised regions required to reconcile the relatively lowLyman-$''alpha$ velocity offsets. Around half of the LAEs in our sample are found to coincide with large-scale galaxy overdensities seen in FRESCO.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05749v2.title: Spectrum of the linearized Vlasov--Poisson equation around steady states from galactic dynamics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.05749v2.summary: We study the linearized Vlasov-Poisson equation in the gravitational case. We identify the absolutely continuous spectrum and give criteria for the existence of oscillating modes and estimate their number. Our method allows us to take into account an attractive external potential. For more information, visit: http://www.nasa.gov/science/topics/geological-mechanics/gravitational-case.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08049v1.title: Dark matter content and dynamical masses of ultra-diffuse galaxies in the Coma cluster
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08049v1.summary: Ultra-diffuse galaxies (UDGs) are spatially extended, low surface brightnessstellar systems with regular elliptical-like morphology found in large numbers in galaxy clusters and groups. Studies of the internal dynamics and dark matter.content of UDGs have been hampered by their low. surface brightnesses.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08048v1.title: Dwarf early-type galaxies in the Coma cluster: internal dynamics, stellar populations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08048v1.summary: We present preliminary results from our spectroscopic survey oflow-luminosity early-type galaxies in the Coma cluster. We also discovered unusual kpc-sized kinematically-decoupled cores in several dwarfgalaxies, which had been probably formed before these galaxies entered the cluster.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08040v1.title: Spatially resolved mock observations of stellar kinematics: full radiative transfer treatment of simulated galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08040v1.summary: We present a framework to build realistic mock spectroscopic observations for hydrodynamical simulations. We use high spectral resolution stellar population models and full radiative transfer treatment with SKIRT. We find that the kinematics produced by Auriga are in good agreement with the observations from the SAMI Galaxy survey.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08037v1.title: Colour jumps across the spiral arms of Hubble Ultra Deep Field galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08037v1.summary: According to density wave theory, we should detect colour jumpsfrom red-to-blue across the spiral arms. Colour jumps are a consequence of large-scale shocks, which also generate the classic blue- to-red age/colourgradients. These shocks have only been detected until now in nearby spiral galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08028v1.title: The impact of baryonic potentials on the gravothermal evolution of self-interacting dark matter haloes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.08028v1.summary: The presence of a central baryonic potential can have a significant impact on the gravothermal evolution of self-interacting dark matter (SIDM) haloes. The presence of the potential induces changes in SIDM haloproperties, including central density, core size, and velocity dispersion, and accelerates the halo's evolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13586v2.title: Extragalactic magnetism with SOFIA (SALSA Legacy Program) -- V: First results on the magnetic field orientation of galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13586v2.summary: We present the analysis of the magnetic field ($B$-field) structure of                galaxies measured with far-infrared (FIR) and radio (3 and 6 cm) polarimetricobservations. We use the first data release of the Survey on extragALactic transformativemagnetiSm with SOFIA (SALSA) of 14 nearby ($<20$ Mpc) galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07940v1.title: Statistics for Galaxy Outflows at $z\sim 6-9$ with Imaging and Spectroscopic Signatures Identified with JWST/NIRCam and NIRSpec Data
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07940v1.summary: We present statistics of $z\sim 6-9$ galaxy outflows indicated by spatially-extended gas emission and broad lines. 5/61 of galaxies with the spatially extended gas at $z/6/9 are an order of magnitude higher than those at low-$z. This can be explained by events triggered by frequent major mergers at high redshift. We also investigate medium- and high-resolution NIRSpec spectra of 30 galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07922v1.title: A Recipe for Unbiased Background Modeling in Deep Wide-Field Astronomical Images
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07922v1.summary: Traditional image processing algorithms are often designed to produce artificially flat backgrounds, erasing astrophysically meaningfulstructures. We present three ideas that can be combined to produce wide-field astronomical data that preserve accurate representations of the background sky. We demonstrate these methods using example datasets from the Dragonfly Telephoto Array.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06321v2.title: GTC Follow-up Observations of Very Metal-Poor Star Candidates from DESI
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06321v2.summary: The observations from the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI) will significantly increase the numbers of known extremely metal-poor stars. The analysis of the data using a well-vetted methodology confirms the quality of the DESI spectra and the pipelines developed for the data reduction and analysis.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07839v1.title: ALMA Survey of Orion Planck Galactic Cold Clumps (ALMASOP): A forming quadruple system with continuum `ribbons' and intricate outflows
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07839v1.summary: Atacama LargeMillimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) Band-6 observations towards a forming quadruple protostellar system, G206.93-16.61E2. ALMA 1.3 mm continuum emission reveals four compact objects, of which two are Class I young stellar objects (YSOs)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07832v1.title: Imaging rotating and orbiting exoplanets with the solar gravitational lens
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07832v1.summary: Exoplanets are not stationary. Their appearance changes as a result of their diurnal rotation and varyingillumination due to their orbital motion around their host star. The nature of the solar gravitational lens is such that imaging with one telescope is accomplished with a cadence of one pixel at a time.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07756v1.title: Impact of Dynamical Friction on the Tidal Formation of NGC 1052-DF2
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07756v1.summary: NGC 1052-DF2 can form due to this tidal scenario by N-body simulation. We find that dynamical friction causes a dramatic decay of the satellite's orbit. Our resultimplies that DF2 can be formed by a more circular orbit within a Hubble time.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07728v1.title: Multi-Epoch Machine Learning 2: Identifying physical drivers of galaxy properties in simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07728v1.summary: Using a novel machine learning method, we investigate the buildup of galaxyproperties in different simulations, and in various environments within a single simulation. We find that stellar mass is built up in a similar way in EAGLE and IllustrisTNG, but significantly differently in the original Illustris. We also apply the technique to the CAMELS simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10851v2.title: Symmetry breaking in merging binary black holes from young massive clusters and isolated binaries
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10851v2.summary: Properties of the to-date-observed binary black hole (BBH) merger events suggest a preference towards spin-orbit aligned mergers. In our analysis, we utilize BBH-merger outcomes from state-of-the-art N-body Evolutionary models of YMCs and isolated binary population synthesis. We incorporate, for the first time in such an analysis, misalignments due to bothnatal kicks and dynamical encounters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.13677v2.title: Evidence for non-merger co-evolution of galaxies and their supermassive black holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.13677v2.summary: Supermassive black holes (SMBHs) grow mostly through non-merger (`secular') processes. Since galaxy mergers lead to dynamical bulge growth, the only way to observationally isolate non- merger growth is to study galaxies with low bulge-to-total mass ratio (B/T) We use the Horizon-AGN simulation to select simulated galaxies which have not undergone a galaxy merger since z = 2.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.13614v2.title: Supermassive black holes in merger-free galaxies have higher spins which are preferentially aligned with their host galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.13614v2.summary: We use the Horizon-AGN simulation to test whether the spins of SMBHs in                merger-free galaxies are higher. We find higher spins in all three samples compared to the rest of the population. We discuss the implications this has for the impact of active galactic nuclei (AGN) feedback. The results suggest that this co-evolution could be regulated by radio mode AGN feedback.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07640v1.title: The EDGE-CALIFA Survey: Spatially Resolved 13CO(1-0) Observations and Variations in 12CO(1-0)/13CO(1-0) in Nearby Galaxies on kpc Scales
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07640v1.summary: We present 13CO(1-0) observations for the EDGE-CALIFA survey of 126 nearby galaxies. We also present annulus-averaged R12/13 profiles for our sample up to a galactocentric radius of 0.4r25. Higher R12-13 values are found in interacting galaxies than in non-interacting galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00019v2.title: Recent Progress in Modeling the Macro- and Micro-Physics of Radio Jet Feedback in Galaxy Clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.00019v2.summary: Radio jets and the lobes they inflate are common in cool-core clusters. They play a critical role in regulating the heating and cooling of the ICM. New numerical techniques and improving computational resources have seen simulations of jet feedback in galaxy clusters become ever more sophisticated.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07627v1.title: Testing Ultra-low Amplitude Cepheid Candidates in the Galactic Disk by TESS and Gaia
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07627v1.summary: Ultra-low amplitude (ULA) and strange mode Cepheids are thought to be pulsating variable stars that are near to or are at the edges of the classicalinstability strip. Until now, a few dozen such variable star candidates have been found both in the Large Magellanic Cloud and the Milky Way.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07590v1.title: Sciences for The 2.5-meter Wide Field Survey Telescope (WFST)
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07590v1.summary: The Wide Field Survey Telescope (WFST) is a dedicated photometric survey facility under construction in China. It is equipped with a primary mirror of 2.5m in diameter, an active optical system, and a mosaic CCD camera of 0.73Gpix on the main focus plane. The installation of WFST in the Lenghu observing site is planned to happen in the summer of 2023.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.01829v2.title: Source counts at 7.7 to 21 $μ$m in CEERS field with James Webb Space Telescope
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.01829v2.summary: Source counts are an important tool that provides information on galaxy formation and evolution. Source counts delve up to 100 times deeper than those achieved by previous generations of infrared space telescopes. In a follow-up study, we utilize our source counts to establish a new IR galaxypopulation evolutionary model that provides a physical interpretation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12100v3.title: 3D Radiation-Hydrodynamic Simulations Resolving Interior of Rapidly Accreting Primordial Protostar
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12100v3.summary: 3D radiation-hydrodynamic (RHD) simulations follow the rapidly accreting protostars resolving the stellar interior. The results suggest that we need to consider the rapid stellar rotation to help us understand the 3D protostellar evolution in the supermassive starformation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07424v1.title: Early Growing Supermassive Black Holes Strengthen Bars and Boxy/Peanut Bulges
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07424v1.summary: Using N-body simulations we explore the effects of growing a supermassive black hole (SMBH) prior to or during the formation of a stellar bar. We show that if an SMBH is introduced early and the bar forms around it, the bar is populated by different families of regular bar-supporting orbits. By heating the inner disk both radially and vertically, an early growingSMBH increases the fraction of stars that can be captured by the ILR and vertical ILR.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07417v1.title: Closing the Gap between Observed Low-Mass Galaxy HI Kinematics and CDM Predictions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07417v1.summary: Galaxies that inhabit low-mass dark matter halos provide an ideal test bed for dark matter models. The observed kinematics of these galaxies do not align with the dark matter Halos predicted to host them, obscuring our understanding of the connection. We use deep HIobservations of low-Mass galaxies at high spectral resolution in combination with cosmological simulations of dwarf galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07394v1.title: Excited Hydroxyl Outflow in the High-Mass Star-Forming Region G34.26+0.15
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07394v1.summary: G34.26+0.15 is a region of high-mass star formation. The line showed a significant blue-shifted asymmetry indicative of molecular gas expansion. We discuss a scenario where the OH absorption is tracing the remnants of a pole-on molecular outflow that is being ionized inside-out.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07374v1.title: Asymmetries in random motions of neutral Hydrogen gas in spiral galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07374v1.summary: The Triangulum galaxy (M33) exhibit a bisymmetric perturbation. This is aligned with the minor axis of the galaxy. To investigate if perturbations in the velocity dispersion of nearby galaxies are comparable to those of M33, the sample is extended to 32 galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07338v1.title: Cosmic Sands II: Challenges in Predicting and Measuring High-z Dust Temperatures
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07338v1.summary: We find that, especially for the most massive objects in our sample, neglecting to account for far-infrared dust can significantly bias the dust properties derived from SED modeling. Anisotropies in infrared emission, driven by the clumpy nature of early star and structure formation, leads to an orientation angle bias in infrared luminosities and apparent dust temperatures.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07336v1.title: Yellow Supergiants and Post-Red Supergiant Evolution in the Large Magellanic Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07336v1.summary: The empirical evidence for an upper mass limit for the red supergiant (RSG) Progenitors of the Type II-P SNe at about 18 Msun raises questions about the fate of the most luminous, most massive RSGs. Yellow hypergiants, many with extensive circumstellar dust and high mass loss, are excellent candidates for post-RSG evolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07328v1.title: Dissecting a 30 kpc galactic outflow at $z \sim$ 1.7
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07328v1.summary: We present the spatially resolved measurements of a cool galactic outflow in the galaxy RCS0327. We probe the cool outflowing gas, traced by blueshifted Mg II and Fe II absorption lines, in 15 distinct regions of the same galaxy in its image-plane. Different physical regions, 5 to 7 kpc apart within the galaxy, drive the outflows at different velocities.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07320v1.title: UNCOVER: Candidate Red Active Galactic Nuclei at 3<z<7 with JWST and ALMA
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07320v1.summary: The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) is revolutionizing our knowledge of galaxies and their actively accreting black holes. Using the JWST Cycle 1.Treasury program Ultradeep NIRSpec and NIRCam ObserVations before the Epoch of.Reionization (UNCOVER) in the lensing field Abell 2744, we report the.identification of a sample of little red dots at $3 < z_{\rm{phot}} < 7$ that likely contain. highly-reddened accrets.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07316v1.title: Simulations of spin-driven AGN jets in gas-rich galaxy mergers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07316v1.summary: In this work, we use hydrodynamical simulations to explore the effects of an AGN jet feedback on the progression and outcome of the major merger of two gas-rich galaxies. We find that the jets drive large-scale, multiphase outflows which launch largequantities of cold gas out to distances greater than 100 kpc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.01536v2.title: Ionized gas kinematics and chemical abundances of low-mass star-forming galaxies at $z\sim 3$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.01536v2.summary: We selected 35 low-mass SFGs from deepspectroscopic surveys based on their CIII]1908 emission. We characterized the galaxies' gas-phase metallicities and carbon-to-oxygen (C/O) abundance using a Te-based method via the OIII]1666/[OIII]5007 ratio and photoionization models. We find line ratios characteristic of high-ionization conditions powered by massive stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.07433v2.title: Target Selection and Sample Characterization for the DESI LOW-Z Secondary Target Program
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.07433v2.summary: The DESI LOW-Z Secondary Target Survey has already obtained over 22,000 redshifts of dwarf galaxies. We employ a convolutional neural network (CNN) to select high-priority targets. We also demonstrate that our CNN selections $z<0.03$ galaxies from the photometric cuts subsample subsample at least ten times more efficiently.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07194v1.title: The Rapid ASKAP Continuum Survey IV: continuum imaging at 1367.5 MHz and the first data release of RACS-mid
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07194v1.summary: The Australian SKA Pathfinder (ASKAP) is being used to undertake a campaign to rapidly survey the sky in three frequency bands. The first pass of the Rapid ASKAP Continuum Survey (RACS) at 1367.5 MHz in the low band has already been completed, with images, visibilitydatasets, and catalogues made available to the wider astronomical community.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07189v1.title: Searching for Radio Outflows from M31* with VLBI Observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07189v1.summary: M31* provides a rare but promising opportunity for studying the physics of blackhole accretion and feedback at the quiescent state. Previous Karl G. Jansky observations with an arcsec resolution have detected M31* as a compact radio source over centimeter wavelengths. The steep radioSpectrum suggests optically-thin synchrotron radiation from an outflow driven by a hot accretion flow.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.16119v4.title: The complex organic molecular content in the L1517B starless core
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.16119v4.summary: Complex organic molecules (COMs) are enhanced in                the gas phase toward their outer and intermediate-density shells. Chemical complexity in these cores seems to increase over time, with N-bearing molecules forming first and O-bearing COMs forming at a later stage as a result of the catastrophicdepletion of CO.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16679v3.title: Pitfalls in applying gravitomagnetism to galactic rotation curve modelling
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.16679v3.summary: The flatness of galaxy rotation curves at large radii is generally considered to be a significant piece of evidence in support of the existence of dark matter. Several studies have claimed that post-Newtonian corrections to the equations of galaxy dynamics may remove (at least to some degree) the need for dark Matter. A few recent studies have examined these claims and identified errors in their reasoning.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07143v1.title: Measurement of the scaling slope of compressible magnetohydrodynamic turbulence by synchrotron radiation statistics
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07143v1.summary: The paper uses synthetic synchrotron observations to explore the scaling slope of the underlying MHDturbulence. The new statistics $X$ and $Y$ can extend the                inertial range of turbulence to improve measurement reliability. The synergy of multiple statistical methods can extract more reliable turbulence information from the huge amount of observation data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07141v1.title: The VVV near-IR galaxy catalogue in a Northern part of the Galactic disc
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07141v1.summary: The automated identification of extragalactic objects in large surveysprovides reliable and reproducible samples of galaxies in less time than human interaction. We present the methodology for the automatic classification of galaxies and non-galaxies at low Galacticlatitude regions using both images and, photometric and morphological near-IR data from the VVVX survey.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09357v1.title: Deep learning of quasar lightcurves in the LSST era
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.09357v1.summary: Deep learning techniques are required for the analysis of synoptic light curves in massive data of quasars. In this follow-up study, we introduced an upgraded version of aconditional neural process (CNP) embedded in a multistep approach. We present a case study of a stratified set of the u-band light curves for 283 qu asars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07053v1.title: Subhalo abundance and satellite spatial distribution in Milky Way-Andromeda-like paired haloes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07053v1.summary: Paired haloes tend to reside in a more isotropic environment than isolated haloes. The shear tensor of their large-scale tidalfield is possibly responsible for this difference. The results in this study indicate the paired configuration could bring some nonnegligible effect on the subhalo abundance in the Milky Way.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07051v1.title: Transition from small-scale to large-scale dynamo in a supernova-driven, multiphase medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07051v1.summary: Magnetic fields are now widely recognised as critical at many scales togalactic dynamics and structure. Models that impose galactic magnetic fields cannot reliably capture their dynamical structure nor interactions with phases within the interstellar medium (ISM) Dynamos must be modelled to create such magnetic fields. ISM models exist in which a small-scale dynamo (SSD) drives a large-scale magnetic field.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07044v1.title: On the origin of the planetary nebula M 1-16. A morphokinematic and chemical analysis
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07044v1.summary: M 1-16 is a Type I PN with a central star of PN (CSPN) mass in the range of $0.618-0.713$ M$\odot. A kinematical age of $8700yr has been obtained from the model assuming an homologousvelocity expansion law and a distance of 6.2$\pm$1.9kpc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07016v1.title: Interstellar Polarization Survey III: Relation Between Optical Polarization and Reddening in the General Interstellar Medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.07016v1.summary: Polarization efficiency describes the polarization intensity fraction per reddening unit, P$_V$/E($B-V), related to the interstellar dust grains and magnetic field properties. Infrared observations from $Planck$ satellite have set the maximum polarization efficiency to 13$\%$ mag$^{-1}$. The analysis of polarization efficiency observations across the Galaxy contributes to the study of magnetic field.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06980v1.title: A CO Funnel in the Galactic Centre: Molecular Counterpart of the Northern Galactic Chimney?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06980v1.summary: A funnel shaped emission feature has been discovered in the Galactic centre. The structure is located 100 pc above the Galactic plane. It is believed to be the radio counterpart of the northern lobe of the 430 pc radio bubble. The velocity of the funnel is consistent with previous radio recombination line measurements.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03230v2.title: Environments of red nuggets at z~0.7 from the VIPERS survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.03230v2.summary: Red ultra-compact massive galaxies, called red nuggets, were formed at high redshifts. Survivors, known as relics, are believed to remain almostunchanged since their formation. We found that the increasing fraction of red galaxies, when moving to denser environments, is driven by the red massive normal-size galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06916v1.title: A Decade of Near-Infrared Variability in NGC4388: Insights into the AGN Structure
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06916v1.summary: Spectral variability of the Seyfert 1.9/2 galaxy NGC4388 spanning five epochs. The contribution of warm dust (T~800K) declined by 88%during these 10 years. This is the first spectroscopic study in the NIR for an AGN where the central source is not directly visible.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08172v2.title: Exploring binary black hole mergers and host galaxies with Shark and COMPAS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08172v2.summary: We explore the connection between the gravitational wave (GW) merger rates ofstellar-mass binary black holes (BBH) and galaxy properties. We find that metal-rich and massive galaxies are 10 times more likely to haveGW events. Theimplications of this work can be utilised for constraining stellar evolution models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06869v1.title: On the origin of the anomalous gas, non-declining rotation curve and disc asymmetries in NGC253
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06869v1.summary: We present a multi-wavelength study of star formation feedback on the kinematics of the interstellar medium in theculptor Galaxy, NGC253. We separate the anomalous gas from the disc using a custom-made line profile fitting toolkitcalled FMG. We find that at $R > 7.5~\mathrm{kpc}$ the starformation activity is strongly lopsided.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06863v1.title: Flux evolution of superluminal components in blazar 3C454.3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06863v1.summary: The kinematic behavior of superluminal components observed at 43GHz were model-fitted with their light curves interpreted in terms of their Doppler-boosting effect. For both B4 and B6 which were ascribed respectively to the jet-A and jet-B of the double-jet structure assumed for Blazar 3C454.3, their kinematics were well model-fit with their bulk Lorentz factor and Dopplers factor (as function of time) The light curves of the radio bursts associated with knot B4 neurotransand knot B6 can be well explained in

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11134v3.title: Microlensing and multi-images problem of static spherical symmetric wormhole
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.11134v3.summary: The gravitational microlensing effect of wormholes has made great progress. In this paper, we find the relationship between then-th order lens equation and the radial state coefficient (RSC) Our results show that larger throat radius and RSC will lead to the larger values for magnification and event rate.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06832v1.title: Classification of Chandra X-ray Sources in Cygnus OB2
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06832v1.summary: We have devised a predominantly Naive Bayes method to classify the optical/IRmatches to X-ray sources detected by Chandra in the Cygnus OB2 association. We use Principal Component Analysis of photometric magnitudecombinations to isolate the best axes for classification. We find that about 6100 objects are members, 1400 are background, and 500 are foreground.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00782v4.title: Discovery of Extended Fe K$α$ Complex X-ray Emission in NGC 5728: Ultra-Fast Outflows at Kiloparsec Scales?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00782v4.summary: We present Chandra ACIS imaging spectroscopy results for the extended(1.5"-8") hard X-ray emission of the Compton thick (CT) Seyfert NGC 5728. We find spectrally and spatially-resolved features in the Fe K$\alpha$ complex(5.0-7.5 keV), redward and blueward of the neutral 6.4 keV line.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06670v1.title: Shear, writhe and filaments: turbulence in the high latitude molecular cloud MBM 40
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06670v1.summary: High latitude molecular clouds (HLMCs) with no evidence of internal starformation, such as MBM 40, are excellent sites for studying the chemistry andynamic evolution of the cold neutral ISM. We analyzed new and archival data from Five College Radio Observatory (FCRAO), Onsala SpaceObservatory (OSO), Arizona Radio Observatory and W. Gordon telescope.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04409v2.title: An Observed Transition of Galaxy Spins on the Void Surfaces
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.04409v2.summary: In simulations, the galaxy spins exhibit parallel alignments in the mass-range lower than a certain threshold. The threshold depends on redshift, web type, and background cosmology. This study presents a first direct evidence for the occurrence of the spin transition in the real galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06572v1.title: Triple spiral arms of a triple protostar system imaged in molecular lines
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06572v1.summary: Most stars form in multiple star systems. For a better understanding of theirformation processes, it is important to resolve the individual protostellar components and surrounding envelope and disk material at the earliest possible formation epoch. Here we present the ALMA observational results of a young                multiple protstellar system, IRAS 04239+2436, where three well-developed large spiral arms were detected in the shocked SO emission.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06501v1.title: The first fireworks: A roadmap to Population III stars during the Epoch of Reionization through Pair Instability Supernovae
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06501v1.summary: The launch of JWST and other scheduled missions aimed at probing the tumultuousdistant Universe, we are entering a new promising era for high-$z$ astronomy. One of our main goals is the detection of the first population of stars(Population III or Pop III stars), and models suggest that Pop III starformation is allowed well into the Epoch of Reionization.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06823v2.title: The Strength of the Sheared Magnetic Field in the Galactic's Circum-Nuclear Disk
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.06823v2.summary: High-resolution polarimetric observations from SOFIA/HAWC+ have revealed the inferred plane-of-the-sky magnetic field (B-field) in the Galactic center's Circum-Nuclear Disk (CND) The B-field is mostly aligned with the steamers of ionized material falling onto Sgr A* at large, differential velocities (shear) In such conditions, estimating the B- field strength with the ``classical'' Davis-Chandrasekhar-Fermi (DCF) method does not provide accurate results.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06454v1.title: Variation of optical and infrared properties of galaxies with their surface brightness
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06454v1.summary: Low surface brightness galaxies (LSBs) are often considered dust poor. This work provides a large catalog of LSBs and HSBs with detailed measurements of their optical and infrared physical properties. We found that the star formation rate and specific infrared luminosity remain mostly flat as a function of surface brightness.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.10566v3.title: Scanning For Dark Matter Subhalos in Hubble Space Telescope Imaging of 54 Strong Lenses
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.10566v3.summary: Cold dark matter (DM) model predicts that every galaxy contains thousands of DM subhalos. The subhalo are invisible, but could be detected via strong gravitational lensing. They lie on the line of sight to amultiply-imaged background source, and perturb its shape.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06433v1.title: Rapidly Rotating Massive Pop III stars: A Solution for High Carbon Enrichment in CEMP-no Stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06433v1.summary: Very metal-poor stars that have no heavy elements are known as CEMP-no stars. These stars are thought to have been produced from a gas polluted by the supernova (SN) ejecta of the very first generation (Pop III) massive stars. We find that rapidly rotating models that reach the QCH state can eject large amounts of C in the wind.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12800v3.title: Integral Field Spectroscopy of the Cometary Starburst Galaxy NGC 4861
http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12800v3.summary: Using the PMAS Integral Field Unit on the Calar Alto 3.5m telescope we studied the southern component of the `cometary' starburst galaxy NGC 4861. Mrk 59 is centred on a giant nebula and concentration of stars                1 kpc in diameter. Strong emission points to a star-formation rate at least 0.47 kpc.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06392v1.title: New insights into the role of AGNs in forming the cluster red sequence
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06392v1.summary: The Spiderweb protocluster at $z=2.2 is one of the most extensively studied protoclusters. This study argues that a third of them are more likely to be "passively-evolving" galaxies with active galactic nuclei. This provides new insights into the role of AGNs in forming the present-day universe's red sequence.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06372v1.title: A tera-electronvolt afterglow from a narrow jet in an extremely bright gamma-ray burst 221009A
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06372v1.summary: Some gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) have an afterglow in the tera-electronvolt (TeV) band. We report Observations with the Large High Altitude Air Shower Observatory of the bright GRB 221009A. More than 64,000 photons were detected within the first first3000 seconds.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19192v2.title: GMCs and their Type classification in M74: Toward understanding star formation and cloud evolution
http://arxiv.org/abs/2305.19192v2.summary: We investigated the giant molecular clouds (GMCs) in M74 (NGC 628) obtained by the PHANGS project. In total, 432 GMCs were identified, where theindividual GMC Types are 65, 203, and 164, for Type I, Type II, and Type III,respectively. The size and mass of the GMCs range from 23 - 237 pc, showing a trend that mass and radius progressively increase from Type I to II to III.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06348v1.title: Revealing the Chemical Structure of the Magellanic Clouds with APOGEE. I. Calculating Individual Stellar Ages of RGB Stars in the Large Magellanic Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06348v1.summary: Stellar ages are critical for understanding the temporal evolution of agalaxy. We calculate the ages of over 6000 red giant branch stars in the LargeMagellanic Cloud (LMC) observed with SDSS-IV / APOGEE-S. Ages are derived usingmulti-band photometry and spectroscopic parameters.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06326v1.title: Period-Luminosity Relations for Galactic classical Cepheids in the Sloan bands
